headline: Good People but Terrible Leadership and Culture
pros:
- Worked worked with great people
- Had fun when left to deliver projects without JLR politics
cons:
(1) No real leadership. Every level of management 'escalates' (essentially defers responsibility) until you reach the Executive Board. Managers are more concerned with looking good and talking about what car they are picking next on the scheme.
(2) To many lifers who are just coasting or have no idea about what is needed to make the business work. They hide behind bad processes or 'escalate' (see point 1).
(3) Promotion is not based on ability - it is based on who you know, if your face fits, or if you say yes enough to appropriate people. I have seen too many excellent colleagues overlooked for yes-men/women.
(4) Lip service to 'well being'
(5) Inflated ego's at all levels of working. Because the management layer is poor quality, people think that they should managers too (anyone can do it mentality cos its so easy) so teams function poorly. The few good managers are not aspired.

headline: Undervalued \ work stress

Client Managers should do more to support Client Service Advisers when they have heavy work loads. Lots of Client Service Advisers leaving Aon as they cannot cope.

headline: A very special place
pros: Great people and values can be felt throughout the organisation. Technology up to scratch and organised levels of work, the organisation thinks quite deeply about its processes and wider impact of its work. Seems to have an attitude of 'lets do this right' as opposed to 'lets get this done'. Strong vision and leadership from the top, good number of females in senior positions. Strong family values and each staff member treated fairly. Strict enforcement of 'no calls policy' at lunch time along with after 5pm which I really appreciate. I've worked in loads of places and Tesco is by far the most inclusive and special.
cons: Unclear promotion laddering and progression to next grade

headline: Toxic work environment

*Gain experience in fast passed retail industry
*Great discount
cons:
*Unmanageable expectations with little to no resources 
*Senior and upper management fail to support middle managers and support staff at the most basic level.
*There is no actual qualified HR department for a global company
*Head office turnover is very high in departments due to toxic nature of blame shifting
*Senior management do not tend to cooperate with each other and are often at odds. Which leads to unnecessary conflict and missed opportunities 
*Poor communication and guidance from the entire organisation
*Mental heath is not taken into consideration
*Little to no documentation of processes or procedures

headline: No progression, and no performance pay
pros: Easy job for life if you don't wish to better yourself and plod along until retirement
cons:
Quite a few colleagues are dire and management do nothing to deal with poor performers.
No opportunity for a pay rise, performance reward system is flawed and only works for those who network with upper management.
Only way for salary increase is to apply to another job and then negotiate. The framework for most jobs is that they don't fall under grade progression and no matter how much you learn, you are tied to whatever salary you started on, plus the company wide negotiated pay rise which is usually below inflation.

headline: Big company with a family feel
pros:
The company is very supportive of employees with good benefits and incentives.
During the COVID - 19 period when I was furloughed I received full pay and when at work safety is the top priority. Plenty of support to work from home where possible and to make the workplace safe if not.

Huge amount of training available to enable you to do your job well and more for those who want to progress their career.

Great encouragement to be environmentally and socially responsible, I've taken my charity day paid leave each year and they have added £1,000 donation to a charity I have raised funds for.

Team spirit is excellent, a surprising 'family feel' for such a large organisation.
cons: You have to work hard for the rewards, new projects become 'business as usual' and another new project added! Resourcing is very tight.

headline: Good environment, challenging work, space to shine
pros:
- Great People: Employees are smart, helpful and caring. I've worked closely with many colleagues in different squads and tribes, and really enjoyed working with everyone. There's a strong focus on sharing knowledge and enabling people's voices to be heard.

- Large impact: We're continuing to grow our user-base at a high rate, which means your work helps a large number of people. The experience of real users is generally very positive.

- Career Advancement: Many of my colleagues have been promoted, with some gaining more leadership roles. There is a renewed focus on recognizing employees performance, and the on-going changes to the review process give me confidence this will continue.

- Compensation: Salary for London Engineering is solid, even better when the stock scheme is included. I can't speak for other areas of the business.
cons:
- Shifting Team Structures: I have been through at least 3 major re-orgs. These are preceded by lack of clarity on objectives, and followed by lack of cohesion between the resulting teams. As a company scales this will happen, but we need to be more careful when and how this is done.

- Shifting Focus: Some areas of the business have become slowly neglected over time, either through technology change (i.e. mobile) or due to leaders leaving and not being replaced. Lack of domain knowledge and lack of support will hurt us in the future.

headline: Good, if you drink the Kool-Aid...
pros:
+ A very reputable brand to work for in the enterprise software and SaaS space.

+ Huge range of products that can fit into all different parts of an enterprise.

+ Strong revenue projections and big growth aspirations.

+ (Mostly) clear and transparent communications from leadership and senior management.

+ Open feedback culture, with regular employee surveys and check-ins—with employee survey results being published openly across the organisation.

+ Clear corporate strategy and goals, which trickles down to each employee through the V2MoM process.

+ Outstanding benefits package and above-average pay rates.

+ Open, sharing culture, with seemingly endless resources available.

+ Strong support network within the SE organisation and a willingness to help from other SEs.

+ Lots of internal resources around talent development and career development. 

+ A very generous education allowance (£5,000 in the UK) that can be put towards almost any course of your choice to help further your career and development.

+ Excellent treatment of a global workforce mostly working from home, such as home office allowances, extra days off etc.
cons:
- Anyone not in a direct quota carrying roles is treated as a second-class citizen, and the sales side of the business (e.g. account executives and sales leadership) is revered and constantly lauded on internal calls.

- Obsessive fixation on hitting quotas and revenue targets, which drives a culture of upselling (even when the customer doesn't really need it—despite their "Customer Success" value).

- It is difficult to relate the SE pay and bonus to company performance—despite ever-growing revenues and beating last year's results, this never really translates into a significant increase in pay/bonus.

- Murky promotion and career progression process that gets called out every year in the employee survey, but nothing really gets done about it. Hiring budget seems to be spent on bringing in more AEs (the quality of which varies considerably).

- The open, sharing culture has led to oversharing, and useful information and documents are scattered across a load of different sources (Google Drive, Quip, Slack, various Salesforce orgs)—with no single way of searching across all of these.

- Lots of internal "noise", which can distract from the day job (webinars, endless all-hands calls, irritating Slack channels etc).

- Internal culture can feel a bit cultish at times and there is a growing disconnect between the US and non-US workforce. You have to drink the Kool-Aid to get ahead.

- The internal Salesforce org (Org62) is a mess making it very difficult to navigate, Lots of duplicate data (e.g. accounts and contacts) across the organisation, which leads to internal fighting over territories/customers.

- The company swings between big corporate and scrappy startup: some internal processes are excessively bureaucratic and long-winded (e.g. requiring manager approval for a $5 software purchase), and elsewhere decisions are taken on a whim.

- Some employees can feel ostracised if they don't submit to the (exceedingly) left-leaning, social justice obsessed political views of the organisation.

- A globally distributed workforce means that emails and Slack messages come in at all hours of the day—depending on the team, internal meetings can start early or run late into the evening.

headline: The people are their best asset
pros: Great colleagues - Accenture focuses on hiring personable bright candidates and it shows. Your colleagues are high quality and dependable. The pay, benefits, and policies (such as the parental leave - 7 months full pay, which can be shared between you and your partner are great)
cons: Cons are broadly to do with consulting rather than Accenture. Be prepared for long hours, you may often have to work weekends depending on your role. It is tough coming in as an experienced hire - they tend to come in a grade below there level of experience to help them get used to the culture, but then get promoted quickly. Whilst it sometimes ‘sold’ as an experience to try different things, in reality you get rewarded better if you don’t move around. This can be an expectation gap for new hires. Particularly if you want to make the most of the innovation areas of the business.

headline: Great place for for a short terms, not so great for the long term.
pros:
- Great benefits, pension plan, holidays scheme etc.
- Good place to meet new friends for life.
- If you know the right people within the company, will you be able to progress into other roles quite easily.
cons:
The following is based on my experience and it can be different in other department within the company:
- Targets are being set by (senior) management what are unrealistic due to the tools and programs we have to use (15+ year old, unreliable, and unable to get the right data). You are only able to reach the targets by pure luck or by fraud/bending the rules.
- Consequences are worse for not reaching your targets (read: losing your job) then committing fraud to reach the targets (read: a non-formal warning). 
- When reporting fraud being committed or a GDPR breach having held place to the correct departments, will you get an response that they do not got the proof to take further steps (even while you sent enough proof to start an investigation and or even take the steps needed), and will there sometimes even be an investigation started against yourself in how you were able to get the proof (read: retribution) instead.
- In the 5 years I've worked for the company, have I also reported several issues customers are having on a regular base; during the booking process, terms and conditions on our website etc. Most of them have never been picked up, and so are still an frustration to this day for the customers, even while one of the mottos of the Leadership team is "Think Customer first". And the points that were picked up (most of the times 2 or 3 years after it was first reported), went back to the way it was within the first software/process/website update, a few months/weeks later.
- If you are not willing to start an relationship with someone within higher up in the company, nor have family or friends within management or recruitment, then you will notice that it is (made) as good as impossible to progress any further.
 * as examples: 
E1: Person A worked already for 8 months in an secondment, when a permanent position came available. Due to the process (what is done in double standards, as some people get the full time automatically after an secondment, others have re-apply for the position) did Person A apply for the role again to be able to get the permanent position. This was only given to Person B, who never working it that role before, as recruitment told Person B had more experience within the role Person A was already working in.
E2: For a certain role were 3 position availed, during the recruitment did you had to do an test where you had to workout examples of the daily job and had to answer skills-set questions during an interview. For the test did Person A score 85%, Person B 80%, Person C and D both 60%. Person B was also told that all the info given during the interview was correct. Only did person B not get the job (as well D as C were friends of the recruiter/manager, know to every one)
- Due to the above do you got people in management positions, without having the skills or knowledge to be able to do that job. You will notice this quit easily with some of the responses you get from Team Managers. Senior Managers, Head of Departments: "You do what you think is best, as you know more about the issue and process then I do", "If you say so, then it will be so.", "So in al those years I worked here, I did look at the wrong numbers?(read: targets)"
- Even while it is being said it is an equal opportunity company, the recruitment department for the call center (where 500+ people work) is quite clear that their internal policy is not to hire people with an disability, and is also being made clear to people who start working within the department. (Maybe this as the call center has not even toilets or emergency exit facilities for disabled people).
- The pay is okay, but not great compared to what other companies offer now days.
- You are most of the time just a number within the company, easily replaceable and easily being ignored f you got any ideas, requests or questions. 
- As most people see the company the same way as I've seen it, is the overturn higher then an average supermarket. What causes a lot of good people to leave the company at the first possible option.

headline: Not good at all!
pros: There are no pros. I liked some the staff initially at least
cons:
They would give the best jobs to their favourites, i.e friends of the manager that they hung out with. At least it was like that to start with. It did change after a while so it depends on the manager.

They tell you not to go in if you have sickness and/or diarrhoea as it is the cafe. Fine, BUT if you are off more than twice in a year you got a disciplinary!

So people had to go in otherwise they would eventually get sacked! It makes no sense.
Have a rule to keep customers safe, but punish the staff for it.

Also if you have a family member die, you don't get time off and have to use holidays or sick time but again you will get a disciplinary after the 2nd time if you use sick time.

I called in and was told to use sick time as I had no holiday left after a few days off, but they said if you do, you will get a disciplinary as you have been off sick once!
I had to sort all the death out and funeral but would be punished after my holiday ran out if I didn't go back in.
They don't care at all.

I became disabled and they wouldn't move me to a sitting job so made me quit instead. They said nothing available at the tills even though I couldn't stand any more.
Yep that breaks the equality act.

Honestly they are shocking. There is even more I could go into.

headline: Most boring job in the world
pros:
Good pay for what you do.
Regular pay rises.
Guaranteed breaks.
Overtime usually available (except in summer holidays).
Hourly rate does not differ by age.
Ability to just work during holidays for students or transfer between stores in term time and holidays.
cons:
Picking is so boring and repetitive.
Managers are so anal about pick rates, the time you take your break, uniform and generally make it unpleasant to work there.
Not limiting customer numbers during Covid, so the shop is heaving and unsafe for staff and customers.
Poor communication from managers (we changed from working 4am to 6am and they only put a note on the wall so some poor people turned up at 4am).
Managers always begging you to do overtime.
Early starts (6am usually, was 4am during some of the pandemic and at Christmas).
Don't know what time you will finish - can be over an hour late (and we are blamed for picking too slowly not because they don't have enough staff).
Unfriendly atmosphere in bigger stores.
No opportunities for career progression as the supervisors and managers never leave so nothing better paid opens up.
Just feels like the company only cares about profits.

headline: They care about people
pros: The management style in all the teams I've worked in at the BBC really focus on you the individual, not you the cog in the corporate machine. They focus on how they can help you with your career and how they can help you enjoy coming into work, and letting that translate into productivity (the most productive employee is a happy employee), rather than focussing on numbers and statistics
cons: As a public organisation, they can't pay as much as private companies could (though they know this and try to make up for that by making the culture as good as it can be). You're also slightly caught in the middle of politics and things going on around the BBC when it comes to conversations going on in the public space, (perhaps more so than other household name companies), but it doesn't really intrude on the day-to-day.

headline: Review of my placement year at BT
pros:
BT has great work-life balance, exposure to real-work projects.
BT work colleagues are very nice and friendly. it is so easy to get along with everyone
There are always opportunities every week to get to know others and maybe sometimes to go to pubs and enjoy networking
cons: Sometimes you may find that your line manager may be based in a completely different office and there may be miscommunication as such. from my experience, my manager was only hired once I have joined and started working at BT for 2 months. We might not have the best knowledge about one another and because we were based at two different locations, there were many things that become rather inconvenient for someone new and inexperienced like myself. Not anyone's fault but it was something that was to bear in mind for me.

headline: Clueless from top to bottom
pros: No weekends, literally the only positive.
cons:
- Clueless management 
-  No communication between departments 
- Confusing processes 
- prehistoric CRM systems 
- Relentless system issues 
- Low pay
- Viewed as just a number rather than an individual 

Probably the most inefficiently run company I have ever come across. The company is so big yet there is zero communication between departments.  It’s hard to believe that this is actually a functioning business.  ‘Bancs’ the CRM system that is used is so useless it’s like it is software that comes free with a kids magazine.  Constantly crashes, and is just useless to operate. The processes are utterly ridiculous. Figuring out the Da Vinci Code is simpler than a customer cashing in their pension , as that is how complicated it is. Multiple phone calls required from customers.  Correspondence that is sent out is not clear at all. There’s a reason that customers complain that Aviva are the worst pension provider. Horrendously adapted to the pandemic and consistently used it as an excuse for deficiencies within the company. Management are absolutely clueless. They say that care about Customer service, yet all their worried about is how long the call queue is.  The pay rate is atrocious for the amount that your expected to know. On that point, if you asked 5 different supervisors the same question to do with a policies terms and conditions, you would get 5 different answers. Absolute clueless from top to bottom of the company. If you are fresh out of education and need a job then this is probably ok for a couple of months but nothing more than that and that’s being generous.

headline: Yes and No
pros: Great responsibility given from the start. You are really stuck in the deep end and expected to get on with it. So you will learn alot quickly in this role. Opportunities in whatever interests you is endless. Senior members are really open and approachable. Very little sense of hierarchy.
cons:
Stuck in the deep end can also be a bad thing, as you’re expected to do high level work even if you have little experience and technical knowledge. A very ‘swim or sink’ environment. That being said, if you are stuck on a piece of work, people are happy to guide you, and feedback is very detailed for you to learn and progress.
Very long work hours, advertise as having a great work life balance but this is definitely not true. Be prepared to cancel plans last minute as you may get a request at 5pm for a work that takes several hours. This happens regularly.
For an organisation that specialises in HR consultancy, pay is very under market (especially considering the extra hours you have to work, they even try and avoid increasing you pay in line with inflation), career progression is very slow (you can remain as an analyst for 2-3 years with no pay rise) and annual bonus is a joke (expect no more than £500)
The above two points result in a high turnover, within the executive compensation department and when someone leaves, they dont hire a replacement, instead they pass on the extra work to you. Leading to higher workloads.
Very top heavy. Their are approximately 10 directors, 3 senior consultants and 3 analysts. And as analysts do most of the groundwork be expected to work on a lot of projects

headline: It is what it is, can't complain
pros:
Great for a first job, I joined during my A levels so I could easily earn whilst working part time, it worked around my studies even at university. There are McDonalds anywhere and everywhere so it was really easy for me to temporarily change stores while I was studying in another city. 

You can book time off regularly or easily swap shifts with other people, although changing your set availability is hard to do.

Social life can be good: You meet a lot of life long friends there's also a team social which you typically get to pitch ideas for i.e. paintballing, work drinks.

Easy progression, I joined at 16 and was promoted with a pay rise by 17 and had opportunities to pursue management. Typically if you can do the job, follow most the regulations your work is recognised by management and you can get promotions. Of course this will depend on the management team from store to store, there have been cases where personal politics can get involved but I think it has gotten much better over the years.

Generally I don't regret my time there, it's a fun job you meet some nice people. At the end of the day if you leave by the time you're in your 20s the job shouldn't drive you insane.
cons:
Very very difficult to get more senior positions once you've reached the management. There are very few senior roles available for 1st Assistant, 2nd Assistant etc... and they are very competitive. Some people have been working at the same store for over a decade and still can't get the senior role they want.

Typical retail / service industry problems you get rude or threatening customers, it can be more frustrating when management won't take your side just to keep the customer happy.

Pay could still be better for management especially. With the amount of work that is asked of them £9/10 an hour is NOT enough - people in non-management positions get paid more at other retail stores.

Managers should take the crew's concerns surrounding sexist, homophobic, racist remarks on shift more seriously even if it is just the kids making "edgy" jokes.

headline: Not valued for your work
pros:
The managers are friendly and efficient, overtime available
It is fun to help customers. There is always work to be done
cons: The no 1 concern for me is unfair pay. They have paid new starters more than staff who have been there for years, they used a TUPE loophole to pay us less than new joiners, which isn't fair.  Using a loophole to value you less creates a real sense of dissatisfaction, profit over people. No chance for a real promotion, all promotions are extra work, extra pressure, but no extra pay. You get flex and overtme, but no recognition for your work. Expected to more complicated work, above what you signed up for, on the old TUPE salary, but the TUPE issue in 2018 was conveniently swept under the carpet. Now there is a completely different system, so you can be having IT issues and technical work every day.   You train staff but still on trainee rates yourself after three years and regardless of your background and skills. Working hard is rewarded with extra work but no salary level with non-TUPE staff doing similar tasks. You were told they are looking into making the salaries fair to create a temporary sense of placation - until you give up asking and just leave like everyone else. Undervalue seriously affects your morale and wellbeing - and your sense of job security. Made to feel like you are easily replaceable.

headline: The company has changed in the right direction, better pay, better hours and better progression and years gone by
pros: Progression within the area with clear direction, Brands now work together well within the region, pay is good, treatment from group is better and much clearer from Senior management, hours are now much more livable company now cares about your personal life aswell as your work life.
cons: Head Office processes can be quite cross-wired at time.

headline: Traumatic
pros:
Free food, not much work actually needs to be done, you just need to talk a lot and show presence. The only thing they care about is you doing the helpdesk. You can also volunteer, go to events and doing different stuff to waste your time at work.

There are some learning opportunities.
cons:
If you are ambitious don’t go there. The job is absolute nonsense. The team leads and the managers are there because they are not capable of doing actual jobs, so they find themselves in “managing” and micromanaging. For example, my team leader once was checking how I am sending an email to someone (not client). This job completely shattered my mental heath and self worth, I was so unhappy. And no, the problem was not me, since I left I am doing fine and don’t hate my job that much at any times despite any difficulties that I may have.

My advice to people who are stuck there and afraid to make a move: the earlier you do it the better for you. And no, free nuts are not a reason to keep a bad job. No one’s job should be as boring, annoying and self-humiliating.

headline: Generally acceptable work

headline: Beware
pros: Some excellent colleagues and reasonable benefits.
cons:
I worked at Avonmouth CDC. The attitude to H&S is appalling, in particular with COVID 19 issues. I was deliberately injured by an agency colleague, with witnesses, yet he suffered no sanctions. My injuries are life changing. 

Further, their so called rehabilitation of my condition was to put me on the heaviest physical jobs. They tried to sack me for under performance (eliminate the problem), but they couldn't even follow their own policies correctly and the Union saved me. 

Their training is woefully inadequate.

The management appear to care of nothing but their statistics. I was given no opportunity for advancement either. Eventually I voluntarily left as my physical condition was deteriorating. 

There are also many abusive native colleagues who have worked there for years and seem to think they run the place. The eastern European colleagues and the overseas colleagues are the shining stars in the warehouse, civil and decent, and it was marvelous and an honour to know and work with them. 

I recommend you avoid this place unless you have no other choice.

job_title: Cyber Security Incident Response and Attack Analyst
headline: State of the art, but boring in the long run
pros:
good salary
great benefits (27 days vacation, amazing pension plan)
most people around are great.
You will get your hand dirty with an unbelievable amount of tools. Think about a technology, it is there in use.
When you are done for the day you are really done.
cons:
US centric company, meaning cool projects are done mainly in the US and other regions gets the boring leftovers. 
Internal reorg wanted people to focus on some areas, which means it gets more repetitive.
Not tiered monitoring model, which means even after years you will be due to work "shift weeks" which are very stressful and repetitive, especially during hiring freezes where workload is essentially double.
Requires to answer the phone (call center like) from internal employees that want to report security issues.
It is going to take long time to progress internally. 
I would personally recommend this role to someone not very senior to get more experience, or if you get the Senior role which does not require the monthly shift work.
Management does not say anything about people working more hours than they should, and this is actually appreciated rather than discouraged.

headline: Great company to work for!

I have been promoted and rewarded throughout my time at Randstad and have a clear goal of my next steps too.

Training and development is excellent and is something I would recommend to anyone
cons: My hours can be quite long, I choose to do the long hours as this helps me to speak to candidates outside of working hours,

Everyone is friendly and the office is a nice working environment

cons:
Not investing in the correct tools to assist with stability and speed of resolutions for incidents.
Middle management not doing much for its staff on the shop floor
The disciplinary process is too lenient and staff get away with murder.
Too many staff take advantage of the sick policy and hard working staff who are never sick never get rewarded for their loyalty and effort to keep the BBC stable

location: Cambridge, East of England, England, England
headline: Great place to work, but needs improvement on equality and diversity
pros:
(1) Abundance of funding 
(2) lots of freedom to explore your own avenues of research 
(3) Career service is amazing
(4) Job perks like access to numerous discounts via Cambens, mental health support services
(5) Access to experts in all fields imaginable
(6) Training for anything you'd need to do your research is provided
(7) Very prestigious
cons: (1) Presenting at conferences is highly discouraged unless the manuscript is already submitted. (2) The environment at the department of medicine is very sexist. Not only are most PIs male, but even in the Dep of Medicine Research day, where students and postdocs are given the opportunity to present their work, in an audience with 50/50 males to females, there is a clear bias in the selection of abstracts, with male students/postdocs giving 70-80% of talks. Micro-aggressions towards females are constant.

headline: Just don't
pros:
They MIGHT pay you a bonus. 

Their system is so disorganised & a mess you will likely find you can get away with anything. 

It actually is a sociable friendly environment to work. You do get a good friendship group & it is flexible with a work-life balance. 

It treats everyone equally bad - so it is fair in that respect.
cons:
Management - Their ambitious, lazy & honestly utterly cruel at times, trust me I was one. It's an unhealthy environment. 

They do NOT give a damn about you. From regional managers to your department manager - they really do not care. 

You won't get your bonus - It's reliant on a mystery customer, who feedbacks whether or not product was available or if there were queues - but since sainsburys refuses to replace lost staff that is always the case

As aforementioned, expect to be multi-skill trained (THIS IS NOT A BAD THING) right up until you find you have 8 rollers left to work, you've been called to tills or somewhere else & it's apparently your fault you didn't do the impossible. 

NO accountability for management errors or recognition when you did good.

Literally no advancement opportunities since team leaders don't exist, the company typically externally hires unless you're a brown-noser.

headline: Good career starting point
pros:
Heavy focus on building your own pipeline infrastructure and CI/CD workflows.
You can be on a team that takes care of interesting use cases. There's not a lot of teams with streaming use cases, in most situations it will be batch data
cons:
You don't know exactly what team are you getting hired to. The coding challenge usually needs either Spark or pandas to be solved but there's a possibility that your team doesn't use Spark in their pipelines at all.
There used to be a lot of freedom to build any tool the team wanted but now there's a trend to use common frameworks

headline: Poor training and constantly devolving standards
pros: - Salary, although low, increased year on year.
cons:
- Absolutely zero training given when I first started.
- We were not given access to the vaccine throughout the pandemic even though we were told we were front line workers (and in my role, lived with the residents)
- Withheld £250 from my final paycheck without knowledge or without this appearing in my contract.
- Problems with payroll three times throughout my three year tenure.
- Residents were allowed to move in to the independent living facility even though they clearly were not able to independently live. (blind, housebound, dementia being three examples).

headline: Its ok not great but not too bad
pros:
Paid weekly
Annul bonus
Not much more
cons:
Way too much 'door to door' junk mail to deliver, which customers generally don't like. Most of them goes in the bin as they are very repetitive and irrelevant to most people. It is a lot of extra work to deliver them which is not properly incentivesed.
Management always pushing you to do more, there isn't enough people and too much stuff to deliver.
Not much social aspect to the job there is no staff get togethers. 
Since privatising the whole company has going down hill and turned very profit orientated ditching the customer and employee focus.
Van that we have to use everyday are all in a terrible condition most of them are write offs.
Most days you don't feel like your hard work is being appreciated by management.
Not much progression to get on to. Once you are a post men thats pretty much it.
Early starts are a killer plus you have to work Saturday. Who needs mail on a Saturday?
Holiday allowances are minimal, which you can only allowed to take in whole weeks and can't take long weekends etc.

headline: An excellent company to work for
pros:
I've been an employee at Access for several years, and along with the company's tremendous growth since, I've also grown with the company. Having started my time with Access answering the phones in Support, I eventually have become a developer working on a few of their many great products.

There are great opportunities for progression, and recognition. Along with this, the work/life balance is frequently encouraged. The culture is great, and there is frequent communication from the top down as to how the business is doing. In turn, they also are keen to know the opinions of the employees, and frequently act on the feedback.
cons: There have been times during the company's unusually quick growth where there have been issues, but in more recent years, the feedback loop to management via the surveys has been acknowledged, and acted upon.

headline: Excellent yet interrupted education
pros: Staff are passionate about their subjects and in four years I have yet to have a bad lecturer. Buildings are well maintained and the people are always helpful and friendly. I felt very welcomed and had a fantastic time taking advantage of all of the wonderful societies, clubs and sports before the lockdown. Since then staff have continued to teach in an engaging way and have done their best to get students involved where possible despite the very difficult situation.
cons: I started in 2017 and every single year I have lost teaching time to strikes and industrial action. No effort was made by the university to resolve these issues in a satisfactory way and no reimbursment was recieved for the loss of teaching.

headline: Great brand, great benefits, overcomplicated systems and surprising lack of competence
pros:
+ A lot of investment on infrastructure, staff wellbeing and health and safety. The company invested a lot on keeping the staff healthy and a lot on capital projects every year (at the Ware Manufacturing site at least). Employees worked in looked-after environments and worked with some decent technology.

+ Plenty of opportunities to move around within the same site and across the business. There were plenty of available jobs even during the COVID-19 pandemic.

+ Understanding and supportive work environment. Management is supportive of flexible wor hours and don't ask a lot of questions when unexpected happen in our personal life. The company had promoted paternal leave and other such schemes, and made sure that employees stayed up-to-date with what happened around the business. They also promoted events at other sites and had active employee groups.
cons:
- Lack of competence, especially in management. The Ware Maufacturing site (probably similarly to other sites) was an established and old site in the business. It had a lot of people who started from one job and, through the years, have done a number of roles completely unrelated to their qualifications and exprience. It truly is a place where if you're liked, you're able to get a new job, a job that is often not even advertised. This applied to advertised jobs. The site seemed to have a lot of people in management roles that they were not qualified nor competent to perform well.

- Politics. The toxic, gossipy, soul-killing and time-wasting politics that drive people away. This seemed to be prevalent among middle management for whom someone's loss is their gain. Back-stabbing was also fairly common.

- Waste. The other side of the plentiful investment made by the company. Overpaying and underdelivering was a bitter reality for the site, which suppliers made the most of. GSK has money, and it often doesn't care how well it's spent as long as it's spent This also gave opportunities for corruption. GSK will do well to curb it's wasteful spending.

headline: Good people, areas to learn but pays not the best.
pros: Everyone is like family at grosvenor. Great support systems and lots of room to learn new skills. Managers are nice and understanding. Throughout the whole pandemic, grosvenor have been keeping in touch and keeping us up to date s much as possible. The jobs rewarding and boosts self esteem. Training is offered on the different departments if you want to learn new skills and work in different areas. As a disabled person, I was very nervous about working for grosvenor. However, I needed have worried. The managers have been more than understanding and do their best to accommodate me. I feel included and listened to.
cons: They don't pay extra for unsociable hours. Since the casino is open 24 hours you do tend to work alot of mad hours. For me, this is not too bad as I dont have a family yet. But it is hard to adjust to different sleeping patterns all the time. I think the wages do need a bit of a boost. But I dont blame them for putting that off because of the current pandemic.

headline: Full of talented people, but the company is frustratingly reluctant to invest in them!
pros:
Full of talented people with impressive knowledge of the airline industry.
Collaborative atmosphere.
Employees are proud of their work and genuinely want the best for BA customers.
Big fan of the new CEO Sean Doyle - confident he will be great for the company.
cons:
Complex processes and ageing technology can slow things down.
Appreciate the company is in a crisis, but I feel they have been complacent in investing in their people. Even before the pandemic, there were poor financial incentives and other perks despite several years of strong profit. 
Many have worked incredibly hard for the company throughout the pandemic, and they have made no attempt to reward these employees.
The company is progressive and moving in right direction, but I feel more could be done to improve gender and BAME representation in senior leadership.

headline: Working at The Access Group (UK)
pros:
There is a great deal of support for staff to develop, enhance skills, be creative and share their expertise with colleagues and customers. 
Access has been proactive throughout the Covid-19 pandemic, supporting staff to work safely from home, regularly checking in on team members, but on how they are - not just focussed on work and targets, so there is a genuine focus on wellbeing and encouraging staff to 'get away from their screens, take breaks, don't extend the working day to include the commute you used to have...'
It is refreshing to work for such an organisation where the first pandemic focus was to support our team to work safely and look after their physical and mental wellbeing (we have trained Wellbeing champions to support colleagues), then look immediately at how we could creatively support our customers (I am in the Health and Social Care Division), through innovative changes to the software to support early identification of symptomatic clients / residents / people supported, then how to ensure they are cared for appropriately and by staff who are reminded to follow Infection Prevention guideline and PPE requirements.
We enhanced our care planning solutions, added functionality to our rostering solution, created new Audits focussed on Covid-19 and Business Continuity, created a Visitor Booking solution for Care Homes and eLFY (e-Learning For You) courses to support the quick and safe onboarding of staff. We then ran webinars and created a support portal for customers to access best practice ideas, etc.
I'm proud of the work we do and the team I am part of. Our CEO and Chief Sales Officer have both created regular update videos to keep the whole team appraised of what the organisation is doing, how we are performing, along with reminding us to share how we are feeling, what help we need, so having that leadership sets the tone very positively for the whole business. 
If you are passionate about delivering and exceeding customer expectations, whether that is in the Health and Social Care Division or any other, Access is a great place to work.
cons: Having been in care provider businesses, the NHS, Banking and Telecoms I think the biggest negative is the perception others have of software businesses and sales people. Now that I am 'on the inside' it is great to know that in the case of The Access Group, those perceptions are not true.

headline: Incompetent and in free fall
pros: There are some good people to work with (mostly TUPE'D), but this company is destroying them and thier mental health, so how long they stay may change that.
cons:
This company is in a desperate state of affairs, it's not short term and it's of thier own making. 

Staff surveys are habitually delayed, cancelled, results not shared, or covered up. Maybe some locations are better than others but Reading and Stirling are and have been horrifically managed since M&G Pru handed over its staff to this inept company. If they didn't threaten staff about sharing their views like the KGB you'd see even more reviews like this on here. There was a witch hunt last time the senior HRBP read these reviews. 

The company are in the business of outsourcing, so why do their flagship systems not work without huge numbers of manual fudging yet to be fixed over a year later? Why do they sign up to new work (for a hefty fee) charging their clients for work then not providing their admin teams with any additional headcount and leaving them to drown in work?

Where is the business transformation model? Why doesn't anyone in any leadership know or talk about the road map or how or when anything will improve?

Why is it necessary to pluck staff and managers out of struggling business areas in to unfamiliar work with zero notice in a literal panic in order to fix yet more avoidable problems elsewhere?

Does this sound like a well run business where the leadership trust thier staff and vice versa, no? Indeed it's about as far from it as possible, and a horrible demoralising working environment, even when you work with good people as they too get ground down. 

This is the daily reality for many many staff here, I made the decision to walk to save my mental health from further damage, others will follow.

Do not even consider a job here there are always better options than Diligenta.

location: Birstall, Yorkshire and the Humber, England, England
headline: The worst job I've ever had
pros: None. Not even one good thing.
cons:
This is quite simply the worst job I've ever had. At first they paint a happy picture, telling you it's a family and coming across really nice, but it changes as soon as you start to work for them. 

Unless you work on the checkout, this job is hard work and they like to think you're a robot. A usual day working on a department includes working stock, being called to the till to sort issues out, and being bullied by management. You are expected to unload all the pallets of stock which are usually 6 to 7 feet tall with around 30 to 40 boxes of stock, sometimes we can have up to three of these. If you are on your own, you are expected to at least unload around two pallets of stock in a 6 hour shift and get them on the shelves as fast as possible. It isn't that simple though, you are called to the till numerous times during your shift to get items with barcodes or sort pricing issues out. Within your 6 hour shift, you are also expected to clean your department which can be a hard task when you are pushed to get stock out as quickly as possible. 

Management are bullies. At my store, there was a particular manager who was vile for no reason, and in my opinion, shouldn't be in a role such as the one she is in. I heard from numerous colleagues that she had driven people out of the company due to the way she talks to people. She doesn't treat anyone with respect but expects you to continue being subservient. Management also makes errors such as ones regarding hours. Sometimes you aren't given your contracted hours on your rota and if they find out you haven't worked your contracted hours, they blame you for it even though it is their fault for not rostering the right hours, it's also a challenge to chase them up about it as they just do not care.

Chances are you won't get paid properly either. When the minimum wages goes up, they don't pay you the new wage until a month after and then they dont give you the missing amount in the next payslip.

Colleagues are horrible and sly for no good reason and think they're above everyone because they've worked there longer. You also get the typical gossipers who will grass you out to the managers the first chance they get.

I left after just 7 weeks because in that time I had been bullied by management and it just generally wasn't good for my mental health
If you're thinking of working at The Range, don't. Avoid.

headline: Mediocrity rules
pros: Very supportive culture when there is a problem. A lot of focus on mental health. The location (Canary Wharf) and building were great pre-COVID. Flexibility to work from home if needed
cons: Mind blowing bureaucracy. Committees after committees after committees to tick boxes and say if something is red amber or green instead of actually fixing problems. Really poor senior management (some are real bullies). No interest for proper employee development. Keep talking about diversity and inclusion and yet they promote very few women. When promoting they don’t look for real quality of work but about how much BS the person can say. People who have done well and have stayed for many years are those interested to work within the lines of bureaucracy and do the minimum necessary. Anyone who wants to bring innovation and change is doomed to crash against a brick wall

headline: Change of Leadership required
pros: - worth getting feedback on leadership style from direct reports on any future CEO.. if you want to change the company this may not be the best plan as not sure  what needs changing will change... New blood required
cons:
take a close look at departments in particular  when generating revenue and leadership styles ... needs investigation

Former leadership has never dealt with systemic bullying and  bullying within departments.

People Strategy - hidden in  office 
( preCovid) and not inspirational - quite  unpolished. Former CEO brought people strategy in and now needs to move on... Not tackling systemic bullying.

Sales and Marketing strategy tends to dismiss female bias and lacks leadership believing strategy is threatened. Former leadership was supportive of sales and marketing strategy.

PR, Press and external Comms is a bullying strategy and has never been addressed... the turnover in PR, Press and Comms is a joke and former leadership has turned a blind eye because PR, Press and external Comms   has the "right" connections in media strategy. Concerning but true.

Leadership doesn't invest in employees welfare. We have very old building where we boil in summer if at work & leadership won't invest. No interest in motivation.

headline: A great company, under-resourced.
pros:
Brilliant brands, generally managed extremely well.
The people and culture - there are some very talented people in the business to learn from and work with. The culture is supportive.
Lots of diversity in job roles - you can spend so many years at Unilever due to the great range of brands and opportunities
It feels good to work for a company that does good. The sustainability, purpose and D&I initiatives and goals at the core of the company, are really excellent.
cons:
The company is becoming more and more 'streamlined', trying different ways to cut back on costs, and it's resulting in the quality of work dropping, and stress levels rising. The teams are getting more junior, as senior employees often seem to leave. 
Work life balance is very tough to sustain at times.
The company is so big - it's very hard to move reactively due to the politics, and number of stakeholders to align.
They have cut back on training.

Brands you get to work on
And the discounts were great

No career progression or raise, will ONLY happen (e.g a mere 2k more, with a somewhat important sounding title change) if it benefits the manager e.g will mean they have more free time to go to pointless interviews in fancy private members clubs and not do any actual work. 
The head of has no clue what’s going in the team nor do they care, they spend all their time in Knightsbridge and not in the Hammersmith office with their team, once they were no where to be seen for at least 2 months!! 
The whole of the old digital marketing team has left, which speaks volumes!! the new managers they’ve hired are friends they’d made at previous jobs (with hardly any relevant experience). One of the roles was on the careers site for a day before it got taken down and GIVEN to their FRIEND.

headline: Horrendous work culture
pros:
- Many hours
- Sometime a yearly bonus
cons:
Note that this may not apply to all stores. Just my personal experience with one store and what I took away from the experience.
- managers are driven by profit
- managers don't have a regard for staffs personal life and availability, it is expected for you to be available even though you say that you are not
- it is is expected that you do more hours than what you are contracted to do because Asda doesn't want to give full time contracts. Doesn't benefit them and having full time staff makes, them loose money (due to more rights to those staff) so part time workers tend to be pressured to do overtime. 
- when staff whom were contracted to do nearly full time left, a replacement would not be hired. For example we had a full time staff leave and they were still not replaced even after a year has passed causing the current staff to substitute in to cover their shift. At some point other staff left and I ended up doing a job which would need 2 and half number of staff to complete. If you don't complete it you are viewed as lazy or not motivated. The blame is placed on staff even though everyone is requesting for more staff to be hired. 
I've worked for other retailers for many years and this one gave me a lot of anxiety and stress.

headline: They dont care about you your just a number which can be easily replaced
pros: Some drivers are nice and helpful and that's it
cons:
Make sure you have a smart phone as their satnav will take you to the wrong street at least two times a shift.
If you are a little late for work they will give your route to someone else, when you start at 4.30am they expect you to be out within an hour but then you have to find a loading bay, if you find a loading bay you have to find your parcels which most of them are in one place but then the others could be anywhere and you end up looking for them for three hours, and when you are in that early they sometimes are still taking parcels off the lorry as it turned up late and they wont tell you before you turn up so your waiting three hours to get your parcels yet again.
When there is high winds you still have to work at the same price. They expect you to deliver your parcels in the time slots given even though the satnav takes you to the wrong place, and as they dont keep you on the same route you cant get used to finding the difficult properties. 
If you cant find a property and bring the parcel back they will send you back out to deliver it even if that mean it's in a different city.
Working weekends is chaos there about 3 management on shop floor who everyone crowds around so your waiting ages to get some help, on the weekends you still have to deliver to businesses which they know are closed, so you could have 30 boxes to one business which is closed so you have to keep climbing over them to get to other parcels which then eats into your time and if you end up late delivering a parcel they wont care, they have no common sense as they expect you to wear safety boots while you walk from your van to your car and the reason they give is that if you get run over it will save you but in reality shoes are not going to save anything when you get run over, if you refuse to wear the boots walking to your car they will punish you. If you cant find a parcel they wont take it off they expect you to find it so while your searching for it for 3 hours they expect you to deliver on time, you can work 12 hour shifts. Sometimes your parcels can weigh 30kg.
They will lie to you, they hire loads of drivers at busy periods give them false hope but when it's a quiet period they will fire them or force them out.

headline: Bad company to work for
pros:
Uniform provided;
Nothing else to mention
cons:
I used to work in Office Concierge as Elite for almost a year. It`s lack of organisation and communication between Operations and staff. On my second day, when I just came to the site, I received a call that I have to go and cover somewhere else, without even being trained. They changed my working sites and starting times at least 2 times per week. I didn't wake up because my alarm was ringing, I was waking up at 6 am because OC was calling me and changing my duties. 

It would be fine if they would change my site, but when they are calling me at 6:30 am asking to start at 8 am, when I need at least an hour just for travel, I have to go to work without even getting normally ready and having breakfast. 
To cover in Head Office was hell. You have to work from 8 am to 6pm, with 1 hour break alone. This site was too much for 1 receptionist, although no one cared. For this year, I called in sick once, because I had food poisoning. When I called in the morning to tell that I am really sick, it was said that I am not allowed to call in sick because there is no cover for me. Before lockdown, I was sent to 4-5 different sites where I have never even been, to cover lunch breaks. 

When I tried to explain that, I don't want to use public transport 4-5 times per day, because of the virus around, it was said "Then you can walk ''. Of corse, I can walk from City to Mayfair, but it will take me an hour, although you give me 30 minutes to travel from site to site.

Even after lockdown I was still working 3 more days, what I guess was not even legal.

Holidays- This is something even more interesting. Asked for holidays 5 months in advance. Explained that I have family circumstances and health issues, so it`s really vital to go home for me. Was refused twice, even after conversation with my manager.

Not paid overtime. Overtime is paid only if you are working over 50 hours per week.

Client is priority, and no one will take your opinion and point of view, because you are just number in this company.

headline: Really disappointed
pros: It's a job that pays the bills
cons:
Don't believe all the PR. Co-op is not an ethical company that puts people before profit. It is a corporate machine and if you have poor managers, it's a miserable place to work.

The hours are long and the benefits are few and far between. Sadly I believed the spiel that they cared about their employees but really Co-op is just another big employer who's words don't match their actions. 

Throughout the pandemic there hasn't been soap or sanitizer readily available. This has been brought up with managers but nothing has happened. We have resorted to bringing in our own.

headline: Cares about its employees
pros:
1. Great place for work life balance
2. Interesting projects within the company
3. Relatively stable career prospects
4. Senior management take care of their employees
5. Pay is relatively ok compared to its competitors too.
cons:
1. Early stage career growth is age dependent. Performance may change that by +-1year. Anyone young, smart and ambitious should look elsewhere. 
2. The company just settles and doesn't innovate. Management tends to be older, so defaults to doing what worked a few decades ago. It doesn't help that most of the middle+ management haven't worked outside the company, so there's a lot of group think.
3. Decision making is so complex and slow. Good luck trying to procure office pens.
4. It should've gotten out of major O&G a decade ago, it's future is bleak compared to companies that moved faster.

headline: Overall, disappointing
pros: Some very clever SME’s around. Great place to learn consulting with unlimited opportunities and a good set of clients.
cons:
Work/life balance was the worst I’d had in 20+ years in consulting. Often working 5 days a week away from home and on the rare occasion I wasn’t on client site then was in the office - so missed children’s birthdays, parents evenings etc. I now see with COVID that 4 UK offices are closing with 100% WFH, so perhaps the pandemic has moved the firm in the right direction. 

Many of the Partners have come through the ranks from consultants - in some ways it’s great to see this opportunity, but unfortunately you’re left with a set of institutionalised Partners that have never worked anywhere else and are actually pretty inexperienced. This would explain some poor behaviours amongst some Partners that would not be accepted elsewhere. 

The partnership model also has its issues - this is not a hierarchical business with strong management top-down, but run more like a democracy. What you’re left with is a diluted strategy. For example some Partners wanted to do more with SAP, but others see the risks so the firm at the moment is generally not a hands on SAP System Integrator but more a Business Integrator - perhaps the recent acquisition of Keytree will change this.

headline: Not for me
pros: The salary is good compared to other agencies
cons: I joined Hays as an experienced consultant who had previously a successful contact desk billing over 250k a year. The interview process was like the xfactor but was relatively ok. When I started we were told how lucky we were to have secured a place at Hays and that many other consultants across the country would dream to be in our position. Thought that was a little odd and this really was what most employees at the office believed, that they were inferior to others in the industry. We were set unrealistic and unachievable targets which we had to present the outcome off to the rest of the new starters, HR and the MD. As an experienced consultant I put a lot of pressure on myself to achieve these however when I didn’t and was faced with telling the MD, HR and the other new starters it really dented my confidence as failing to hit KPIs wasn’t something I was used to. However during the presentation it very quickly became clear that none of the other 10 new starters had hit their targets either and after speaking with other colleagues I found out that most people didn’t even come close to hitting their targets either when they started. It seems a strange process to put new starters through and certainly caused a lot of us undue stress. I do wonder why Hays haven’t looked at this and changed it as it was clear the targets were unachievable which was proved by not one person hitting them. I guess this would be a fair reflection of how the company is run, out of date and corporate. There was little training on the industry of your desk, I wasn’t trained on payroll despite having 5 people out working for me and the CRM system is hard to use, slow and isn’t fit for purpose. Consultants also don’t have their own numbers which is bizarre, there is an office number which one of 35+ people could answer. I left after 4 months and am now much happier, even if I was ‘lucky’ to have secured the opportunity there.

headline: Good intentions - poor delivery
pros:
Access provide good pay and benefits and the company holiday incentive is great. They reward good performance well and generally treat staff with care and respect. 
They provide good training and have many good people working for them.
cons:
They acquire businesses they know nothing about & change everything to fit their model at the detriment of their customers and existing staff.
People are replaced with access staff and the development of the product slows down or stops - ruining businesses that thrived on being the “cutting edge” of their sector.
The access team aren’t bad people they just have their own ideas and don’t listen to experts within the businesses that they buy.

headline: As universities go, KCL is a good employer overall in my experience
pros: It is brilliant to be part of a world leading research community. I'm very interested in the work that I do and I believe it has value for society more broadly. The people I work with are great. I believe KCL overall is a good employer and has been supportive to employees during the COVID crisis.
cons: I think that your experience of working here depends very much on your department and team. As this is such a huge institution, experiences can vary greatly. The general 'cons' of working in academia and in a large institution apply here too. Due to the size of the organisation and hierarchical structure, processes are very slow and cumbersome. It is often difficult to find the information you need as an employee due to the structure of the information online and the number of people that work here with different responsibilities that are not always immediately clear. I have heard that the working culture in some departments in terms of long hours and presenteeism is a problem, luckily this does not apply to me personally. Like most universities, there is a big problem with diversity and inclusion particularly in terms of the representation of women, ethnic minorities and LGBTQ people in senior roles, but I believe KCL is committed to addressing this.

headline: Not the company I thought they would be - Sadly I would advise anyone against ever working for BT
pros: - High commission (when they pay it).
cons:
- I have never worked for an organisation where so many employees are consistently unhappy/stressed/under pressure.
- Huge divide between management/leadership team and rest of employees, with a "Them vs Us" culture and no accountability from management to help and support their employees, despite constant lip-service claiming otherwise.
- Disorganised, constant changing of rules with little forethought and implementation of new processes that seem to be put in place solely to make it more difficult to get paid sales commission. Some of these changes put in place retrospectively.
- Unnecessary layers of institutionalized middle management who have no clear purpose other than self preservation.
- A "that's not my job" culture, where employees from other departments are reluctant to work collaboratively as they are actively discouraged to work on anything that falls outside of their remit.
- Poor communication between leadership teams and their employees, making changes which are either not communicated clearly or communicated too late. Changes to the payplan took several months to be communicated to the staff they were affecting directly, with these changes in place for that entire period.
- Poor communication between departments, resulting in lack of direction overall and multiple people within the BT umbrella competing for the same customers.
- Constant chopping and changing of segmentation/allocation of corporate customers, making it challenging to build sales pipeline and inhibiting the customers experience. Some sales staff also had sales opportunities taken from them after months of work and given to another employee who was paid the commission despite never even speaking to the customer.
-Obsession with metrics and CRM dashboard information which encourages micromanagement of all employees activity. Employees then just end up gaming the CRM data to satisfy the ever changing KPIs, meaning that the data measured is increasingly worthless. Management then base their forecasts on this incorrect data and apply further pressure on employees when the forecasting is invariably incorrect.

headline: Hopefully doing a big turnaround... heading in the right direction!
pros:
Recent leadership changes (last year) are really prioritising growth.
Very accomodating and flexible place to work.
Amazingly passionate technical teams who LOVE the technologies they work with.
cons:
1. Bureaucracy, bureaucracy, bureaucracy! Totallly siloed business restricts the innovation that teams can actually perform. Business processes are so opaque and varied across business units and even manager to manager.
2. Slow to act on climate goals - employees branded "idealists" for asking climate-related questions in CEO ask-me-anythings.
3. Had to essentially get another job offer on the table to get an overdue promotion. Requests were ignored despite having ~8 senior employee support statements. Ended up happening in the middle of a bad quarter, which gave leadership the appearance of being shocked and desperate. 
4. So many people! IBM has one of the biggest workforces in the world - and isn't moving fast as a result. Definitely adopted Agile (in some teams) but not Lean!
5. Often hard to trace through from corporate strategy to your functional role... but this is getting better with concerted effort from leadership sharing strategy.
6. Very few opportunities for progression in the UK in comparison to the rest of the world - and no opportunity to relocate.

headline: Not all reviews are real, this one is
pros: paid on time, fast recruitment process, free coffee on site, exposure to big-name companies
cons:
cult-like culture
fake people, colleagues and management
a sickening forced positive atmosphere, you could see people smile even if they felt like crying...that was scary sometimes.
micro-management very practiced
lack of support
bullying 
exclusion from important information
clear delimitation between workers and managers, so connection was strained or lacking
under-qualified management
being pushed to do more than entailed in job description at no additional pay
no recognition unless written by oneself, that's just wrong, nobody likes to say "I did this and I'm good at that", it's embarrassing and wrong for management not to see this and be proactive as they preach
cultivate the mentality of "what's your favourite colour? Red. Wrong, it's green, you fail" in which your decision is wrong regardless if its just an opinion, advice or anything like that
decision-makers run from their responsibility so if you do make a decision they jump on you for overstepping your limitations
no empowerment as they are the bosses

there are just too many cons to mention and the overall impression is that the company is rotten to the core, in dire need of replacing the entire high-level management or getting acquired by another firm to change it completely.

headline: Complacent, slow, backwards looking company run by narcissistic management
pros:
* The pay is average for London. There are some benefits like discounts etc but they are nothing to write home about
* If you are luck enough to be placed in a good team, there's the chance to work with some decent tech and good practices
* A longstanding business that's probably not going away any time soon, even if they are in decline over a longer timeframe. Your job is probably safe for 10 years at least
* Sainsbury's diversity and inclusion efforts are surprisingly good. They're pretty active in supporting different backgrounds, educating colleagues and also speaking up if colleagues act insensitively. However, this only goes so far: senior leadership is still very overwhelmingly white, middle-class, English and male.
cons:
* Sainsbury's are one of those business that like to say they are agile, but really all the planning above developer level is waterfall, with multi-year plans, "enterprise architects" who don't code prescribing details years ahead of implementation. Short term planning basically doesn't happen. Imagine all the downsides of waterfall with no benefit, plus no joined up thinking at a lower level
* There is a _huge_ resistance to software practices that have been considered standard in most other businesses for decades at this point, including: automated testing, CI/CD, agile, UX testing (with actual users)
* Lots of people-churn, in the projects I've worked on, average tenure seems to be around six months
* There's a pervasive attitude of "software developer == code typer" in the company, meaning that feedback, ideas, solutions etc from lowly developers are ignored in favour of (often badly thought out or bizarrely ill fitting) ideas from middle-manages with no real-world experience
* Middle-management, eg. tech leaders on projects are, in my experience, either non-technical people with some management skills but who fail to understand technical requirements and caveats, or have been "out of the game" for too long and only understand very outdated practices
* Senior management are - to say this neutrally - out of touch. There are regular all-hands meetings with senior management, however the tone from senior leaders is extremely condescending, especially when answering people's concerns regarding Brexit, Covid, ways of working and the future of the company. Senior leaders (who are all white and middle-aged, 90% male) sit in their home offices overlooking massive gardens in their countryside home, telling the staff who are sat in bedrooms in house shares how we're "all in this together" 
* Covid response has been mediocre. I feel like the company has done the bare minimum to support staff. For example, there are allowances for equipment to work at home like a mouse, monitor, etc, but the spending limits are so comically low as to be useless, eg. a maximum of £7 for a mouse, which buys basically the cheapest non-ergonomic mouse from Argos with staff discount and that's it. The company's lack of support for staff who have family overseas and who have asked for permission to work from abroad is appalling. They have refused to grant permission and refused to explain why they won't allow this. The overall feeling is that the company is run by mean-spirited bean counters who only care about staff wellbeing in the sense that high staff turnover costs them money.
* The company's efforts for social causes like Covid and the environment are "good enough" and the company could do a LOT more. "Carbon neutral by 2040" is a pathetically unambitious target, and exists solely so the company can look like they are doing something.

headline: Terrible. Worst company I ever worked for.
pros:
If you are one of those who like to bathe in your own little pond and/or have no desire to build new/cool things and/or wake up in the morning, do the job and that's it and/or like a "cushy" job...AND if you don't mind all the cons stated below...then it's probably a "good" place.

Note I have added no pros. I guess one would be the pay. 

Other than that, from an engineering standpoint, I really see no other pros.
cons:
I really don't know where to begin...

- Internally, it's a mess of custom-built systems, the majority of which are half-broken. You better follow the few happy paths the systems expect otherwise you are doomed. 

- These custom-built systems, typically have a terrible UI/UX in 80s/90s style. Lacking basic but obvious elements such as a simple link to homepage on the service "logo".

- The documentation for things are obviously not up-to-date, they are patchy, if at all present. People there don't know what "reference documentation" means. When you ask something, they WILL give you vague answers (if you are lucky to GET an answer). You fill find that most people are busy...doing what? I don't know. Certainly NOT focused on simplifying/improving things. I suspect the majority are there to keep their position/role close to themselves. Keep in mind many people are there since +3/5/10 years. Many often openly say their skills are not transferable, which means they either stay there or a lot of effort will be required for them to go elsewhere. 

- The internal services have half-baked and/or badly-baked RESTful-ish APIs (if/when at all available). Again without documentation. 

- Infrastructure as code? Forget it. Terraform is used internally but the in-house built custom resources are broken and or implemented in a bad way. Forget all the goodies Terraform gives you. 

- As a developer your life will be miserable. You will have to live with having to login into a remote desktop, and then maybe onto another box from there. You will have a hard time when it comes to managing your keyboard key mappings. Especially if you are on a mac, using a Windows remote desktop, then onto a Linux box. 

- As a developer your life will be more miserable. Forget using the latest version of IntelliJ or Pycharm or VSCode. You are lucky if you get to use a version from 4 years ago or longer. 

- As a developer your life will be miserable 5x. There is an infinite amount of processes, road blocks, blockers etc when it comes to creating VMs, deploying things, etc. Their internal "cloud services" are the worst I have ever seen. You thought AWS/GCP's UIs/functionalities were bad? Don't be naive. Think twice.

- The internal tooling truly is awful. Skype and Symphony (like Slack, but 10.000 times worse) are used for messaging. Don't get me started there... Then people tend to copy&paste CLI commands/etc into email threads. A true joy when it comes to reading these threads. Ah, and you will have to spend days to fight with Microsoft Office email filtering rules because you will be flooded with meaningless automated email notifications. I am surprised they use Zoom. I believe the pandemic kind of forced them to, in a way...

- If you want to run something on a box, you are doomed to go through MANY hoops and bumps. You thought Kubernetes was bad? They have a custom system which will make you cringe when it comes to working with it. It's bad, and it does not work. 

- Did I mention the internal tooling is terrible? Even at Apple which is a very secretive company use Slack. This alone must boost productivity by MILES. Instead Goldman Sachs uses 2 of the worst tools. Having conversations with people which involves code is the worst of the worst. This is true also for conversations happening over email (Outlook formatting and copy&paste capabilities...ugh!)

- There are people who are literally afraid of criticising the internal state of things and/or saying negative stuff about the company processes/services/etc (which clearly don't work and MANY complain about). They are afraid of saying due to potential retaliation by the company. Read that again. You got that right. 

- There's tribal knowledge everywhere you turn. The internal Confluence spaces are more often than not useless. They are incomplete. Badly written. 90% of time you will spend an absurd amount of time trying to figure out where is the documentation for something and/or how something works. Because guess what - that "something" is a custom thing somebody thought it'd be good to build (bonus hunting anyone?). Add all this to the fact the person that *maybe* knows is on the other side of the globe. So good luck with that. Maybe in a week worth of back-and-forths via Skype/email you will get a definitive answer (because people WILL give you inconsistent and/or vague answers).

I am seriously impressed by how such a behemoth of a company is in such a bad state when it comes to technology. And to think that billions of dollars flow in and out of there. It's all kept afloat by a non-negligible amount of minions which maintain servers and do manual tasks...30% of which could be easily be automated out if only one would follow simple, basic and GOOD engineering practices.

Not everything is bad, sure. But don't be fooled by those who will try to paint you a rosier picture. As the CEO said, it's a bank and not a tech company. If you are one of those who value collaboration, being able to look into other people's code, send PRs, streamline/automate processes, remove barriers, etc. This is definitely not the place for you. 

Look elsewhere. Believe me.
