headline: Poor treatment, poor pay
pros: The discount is quite good.
cons: The company cares more about selling their credit card than actually providing customer service, they bully the staff into pushing this card on customers as well as pushing for emails, they tell you not to ask customers if they want to be added to the mailing list they just told us to tick the box. The pay is poor for what you are expected to do, as a senior I only made 45p more than a sales assistant and I was threatened that my pay would be taken off me if I told others what I made. Money was no better if you were a supervisor, they made 20p more than a senior but they were told to be ‘mini managers’ without the benefit of a managers salary. There was little training given, you learnt on the job and taught be people who were already stretched think while management sat upstairs. Progression was kept for those who sucked up to management and not those who were better or more competent at the job. There is no consistency, in Cheshire Debenhams we went through 6 managers in the four years I was there, only two were actually good at their job and genuinely cared for staff. Staff turn over is awful, we lost 8 members of staff in a few months because the could no longer cope with the stress management put on them. Generally a very poor place to work, staff on the floor were left completely demotivated, it was hard to get staff to come in for overtime as they just didn’t want to be in the store.

headline: Certainly would not recommend a career here
pros: Building is fairly modern and has reasonable infrastructure as well as in house canteen and other services
cons: Firm politics, leadership, zero respect for junior team members, treated like a dogs body rather than valid employee. To put it simply I wouldnt wish working here on my worst enemy

headline: Fast moving, high energy and still manages to feel like a big family
pros:
Amazing revenue and profit growth in the past 4 years, which fuels an environment full of opportunity for all levels of employee. The business is constantly recruiting people from graduate intake level all the way up to board appointments, with internal promotion opportunities at every stage. This enables Access to strengthen and bolster its capabilities and build out a great team. 

When I joined we had circa 1,200 staff and 4 years later we are close to tripling that number...not many UK tech companies that can say that !

Great products in a whole raft of vertical industries, backed up some great horizontal technologies that can be delivered into these verticals. Access are generally No1 or No2 in every sector they operate in.

The business believes in a family ethos and culture, which you can feel part of very quickly. The HRD and wider board drives this culture and importantly delivers great benefits, events and unique perks - such as flying hundreds of colleagues to Spain every year for a weekend on the company !

An amazing company share scheme that is second to none.

If I was starting out or was mid way through my career and IT was my chosen sector, I'd see Access as one of the best places to be in 2021.
cons:
You have to be receptive to change, as change is the one thing you are guaranteed to experience at Access - some people can't always live with that, whilst the majority at Access thrive on it.

Although we are growing super quickly in terms of headcount, sometimes we do run a little hot resource wise which puts strain on the system. My experience though is that this is quickly picked up and rectified.

It's a challenging place as the business is always striving to be best it can be on every metric - if that environment suits you then you will thrive, but if that fast pace isn't your speed then it may not be right for you.

headline: Hollowed out in UK
pros: OK benefits - 35 hours a week, 25 days A/L, pension better than average
cons:
The company is clearing out technical roles from UK - either offshoring to Eastern Europe and India, or taking them to US leaving just a rump of staff in the UK working on increasingly obsolete systems.

The last project I worked on had copywrite notices dating back to 2006. 

There were endless streams of 'management initiatives', "Cultural Values", DSDM, Agile, blah blah all of which were launched with a flourish but usually left incomplete before the next gimmick picked from the pages of a magazine left in the seat rack of a business class airline.

The staff who were based in London at Canada Square seemed completely unable to interact other than by sending emails and IMs to each other as they all sit there with headphones on,

GSK is an outstanding and dear company and is a great place to work, altough if you are joining now you can see the amount of changes as an opportunity or a continuous change stressfull 'not very structured' Pharma machine. Things tend to get better from 2022 onwards but only the market will tell.

headline: More work to do
pros: Mercer has a strong vision and has the potential to be fantastic. The business is in the process of transitioning, and on the whole, has done this well. Pay is varied between different department areas, but you can see there are efforts to try and do the right thing. There is increased transparency on what we do well, and what needs work on. It is a proud firm with a rich history of delivering world class services and support to clients.
cons:
Mercer is a bureaucratic business with a complex structure. It lends itself to poor and slow decisions being made. Often the business chokes itself unnecessarily because of this. The business would benefit from a more flat structure, allocating budgets to departmental heads who can then make quick decisions on how to run the business area. It would make the business far more agile and adaptable throughout the economic volatility we see today. Those closest to the clients understand the challenges that need addressing, and talent management requirements. My overarching concern with the structure is that at the very top and bottom of the business we are seeing alignment in terms of values, culture and strategy, but we have a lot of out of touch, stale and self-serving senior managers and partners who do no have the firm or it's peoples interests are the fore. Instead, it is about self promotion, and as a result, they are poor leaders, out of touch and leave many feeling resentful to work here. The go to market strategy is being undermined by these people as they often instruct their teams do underhand things in order to gain additional revenue. This is not a client centric thing to do and is often brought up in client conversations. Reducing reliance on commission and charging a flat fee with a proposition bundle will improve the perception of the value we offer. If we contracted for 3-5 years, then 

Lastly, in most areas of the business we have specialist on health and risk, rather than being multi-disciplined. Our competitors have moved away from this model as it is inefficient. A client does not want to see 3-4 people on a single call to discuss a renewals. The different teams also are poor at communicating and it does not lend itself to having strategic conversations with clients. Some large corporate clients I think warrant it, but aside from this, it is not needed and it not wanted by clients. It makes us appear outdated and fragmented. The majority of those colleagues who I speak to are unable to have any kind of strategic conversation with clients about this as their knowledge is too narrow, and ultimately, their line managers don't focus on the other benefits as they are not remunerated to care about it.

headline: The C in CEO is for Chaos.
pros:
- Top-class design team. It's a shame that some good people have left or are leaving.
- Great salary.
cons:
- The mission is a lie - Babylon focuses on delivering tech products to big health org (mostly Insurance providers) with the aim to reduce costs to THEM. But it's up to these orgs to reduce their cost to the end-user. Where is the data that shows that we are closer to achieve our mission?
- Senior leadership has no experience with tech - The CEO and other people in C-Suite has no experience with tech or managing product organisations. Their decisions are random and dictatorial creating a chaotic environment.
- There is never time to build the right thing - The business is led by the commercial team and all their short-sighted deals. They decide what goes to product roadmaps. Product teams then need to work in a rush to make sense of the commercial deal and try to build a solution that either meets the user needs or the partner needs. What do you think a CEO who is ex-Goldman Sachs is going to prioritise?
- Design Leaders mysteriously disappear - Product Directors, Heads of Design and Chief Design Officers get fired after doing something that contradicts senior leadership. 
- Poor culture - Long and stressful hours. We say that 1 day at Babylon feels like 1 week, and 1 week feels like 1 month, and 1 month feels like a year. If you care about your mental health, look for somewhere else.
- Lack of transparency - No transparency from Senior Leadership or leadership on what decisions have been made and why.
- No salary review process, career progression and no incentives.

headline: Amazing company! Why are Morrisons only the 4th biggest Supermarket in the UK?
pros:
I really enjoyed my 4 years working at Morrisons. It is a great job as a student and I felt really disheartened having to resign but I guess everyone eventually moves on in life. Here are the pros:
-A bright, energetic team! You will get a long with everyone from the second you start working at Morrisons
-The stores overall working environment is brilliant and the Managers and Head Office listen to all staff and implement views and suggestions
-Regular breaks which is a huge advantage considering the amount of time your on your feet and the constant walking around the store. It is a very fast paced job!
-Great hourly rate of pay which is set to increase! We were also offered lots of bonuses especially to reward our hard work during the coronavirus pandemic. Morrisons cared a lot for their employees during the pandemic. We were given lots of support especially financially! PPE was ready for us immediately. Morrisons reacted very quickly and very effectively towards the pandemic. Moreover, 95% of their temporary staff hired during the pandemic have got permanent positions within the company. Due to current unprecedented times, this is a lifeline for some. 
-10% staff discount which rises to 15% occasionally. During Christmas, we got 20% staff discount at one point. In addition, we also used to get free food (mostly bakery, fruits and vegetables) to reduce food waste and Morrisons are working really hard to reduce their environmental impact which I love! You are allowed free hot drinks on your shift as well.
-Career progression is great. Morrisons really love organic growth! I was offered promotions to Shift Leader but due to educational commitments I had to decline them. I know one person who has worked in Morrisons for 8 years. They went from a Customer Assistant to an Assistant Manager. 
-The training and development you receive is very structured and critical. I have gained a lot of skills and knowledge from this. Moreover, I have seen other colleagues being motivated to apply for Degree Apprenticeships and Graduate programmes which Morrisons offer
-Managers are very thoughtful and considerate. They consider everyone's external commitments (especially for working Mums or University students) I have never had issues with my shifts. Stores are really organised.
cons:
Despite working here for 4 years, I cannot think of much. Everything went well for me and many others. There are only little cons:
-Lots of overtime offered. This maybe a pro for your bank account but eventually it does affect your social life. Personally, as a student I did not mind working almost triple my hours 1 week as I needed the money
-Sometimes, workloads could be overwhelming due to the nature of the job. When everyone was panic buying, I was on the tills for 3 hours straight! 
-Some customers can be really rude and aggressive. I have seen someone fight with the security once because they did not want to wear a mask! Ridiculous!
-I am struggling to think of any!

headline: Great company but consistent cost cutting makes it a less attractive place to stay
pros:
- Incredible iconic brands that everyone in the company is really proud to be part of.
- Fantastic values that the company does its best to uphold (see below re pressures that sometimes compromises those)
- The people. Diageo recruits and promotes some great people. Leadership and management skills are constantly being developed through considered feedback/ in house leadership training. Bonuses are based almost as much on the "how" something is delivered, not just the "what". 
- Great opportunities to work in different offices worldwide. It is not all about HQ in London. (Check Google to see the Sydney office)
cons:
- With what is effectively an 18-24 month organisation restructure cycle, there is a culture expecting those who remain in post reorg to do more with fewer resources. A lot of stressed, over worked people. But people still band together to get the job done.

- Significantly lower payscale vs market. From my own experience of interviewing after leaving, and the role I have just accepted, expect at least a 30% pay bump for the same role outside of Diageo.
- Behind the curve in terms of data analytics tools for finance teams. I needed to study that in my spare time which has helped with my next role.

headline: Overworked & Underpaid
pros:
I worked with a lovely team who had years of experience and very much enjoyed optics and the new things I was learning each day. There was good discounts on boots products and 70% off prescription glasses/sunglasses if you needed it. 
The sick leave and maternity pay was good. In general we had lots of good choices for frames and lens’ with customers. I really enjoyed the job when I first started as it felt like we really cared about people’s well-being.
cons:
Towards the end of my time here during the pandemic when they decided not to bring managers back into store, optical assistants were being overworked and underpaid; being expected to do a store managers job for zero pay increase this led to incredible stress and a day where my entire team cried because of how overwhelmed they was. 
Upper management were constantly making changes to the prices and procedures without consulting their staff on the ground which led to things that were not beneficial to the customer or the staff which clearly someone sat in an office who had no experience of optics had designed.

Lack of training meant there was many who could do one thing but not another and it led to a high turnover of staff as they felt inadequate when they couldn’t do things that they could if they had just had some training. 

The wage for the job you was doing was very small and actually one of the lower paying of opticians. No bonuses or commission made it feel as if it wasn’t worth it. 

The uniform was one of the worst things about the company, cheap polyester uniform that was constantly splitting or tearing and once it did break you could be waiting months before getting a new set. A customer once described it to me as looking militant and I couldn’t disagree with them. 

In my time there plenty of staff left but non were replaced which meant at times you had three people for three clinics and as soon as you had a walk in it meant everyone was rushing around without being able to give proper attention to the customer.

The rule of being stood up all day meant that we looked as if we was doing nothing when customers walked in when actually we had ten jobs in hand that we couldn’t deal with just so we looked as if we were ready to go for the next customer. 

If there is jobs going at any other opticians I would go there over boots, their work politics gets to be too much and you feel very inferior within the company; there is zero room for progression at most points but especially now as they are making staffing cuts.

headline: Amazing people who are undervalued by the business
pros:
Amazing colleagues who are bright, interesting and ambitious. 
The business offers brilliant training opportunities, it's great place to start in an entry level role.
The Guardian is well respected, it stands out on your CV.
You can be proud to work here - Guardian journalism genuinely has an impact that makes the world a better place.
Kings Cross office - great spot for commuting and cool area in general.
Company benefits are pretty good.
cons:
The salary isn't up to par, they rely on the staff wanting to work there out of pride and the fact that it is a nice place to work - this can make you feel undervalued and constantly thinking of what you could get elsewhere.
The 'restructure' that occurred under new management during the pandemic was an absolute mess, people were at risk of redundancy for 6 months knowing they would have to re-apply for the job they already do. This left staff feeling even more undervalued meaning that many of them chose not to re-apply, so now the business is hiring externally - a symptom of a poorly managed re-structure.

headline: Hate it!
pros: Benefits and hours are really good
cons:
Toxic environment.  If you dare reporting something (Bullying, abuse from your Manager, sexism, made up negative comments on your reviews..) you get put on a black list and eventually they (HR or the assistant manager)  will do whatever they can to get you out (by even going as far as making up stories). Staff constantly disappear from one day to the other. Of course no exit interviews for those.
Do not dare having a brain and speaking up in this company. Be a sheep and you will succeed. 
In this company, it is not how good you are at your job but how well you get on with the assistant manager. Your direct line managers will never stand by you however good you are.
Lots of weird people in this company..people who have been in the company for very very long who behave so strangely and constantly look for an opportunity to comment negatively on others.
The Management (PMs or analysts) fail to set up the example. A lot of them just killing time or on holidays most of the time.

headline: Great culture but slow for progression

- opportunity to work across multiple disciplines
cons:
- as with any large companies, systems can be archaic and change is slow 
- very focused on 'Blue Box' and sometimes feels like we are talking to ourselves, rather than looking outside organisation 
- pay not in line with peers and pay rises unable to keep-up with expectations (even during promotions) 
- any potential career growth is slow with an unwritten rule of four years at each band level before promotion (regardless of talent)
- most leaders are Amex-lifers, stifling innovation across business units

headline: Unbelievably Amazing Culture + People
pros: Mastercard have the most amazing people at every level. I feel capable and confident speaking to anyone and everyone about anything, and everyone has time for anyone regardless of who you are or what you do. There's a huge emphasis on the culture and celebration of diversity at the company, which all builds together to make pretty much anyone and everyone feel comfortable here.
cons: Depending on what role or area you work in, you can have very long working hours. However, this is caveated by a very strong internal focus on us as individuals being able to speak to our managers about how we want our work-life balance to look.

headline: Ship without a captain. Avoid.
pros: Nice office, few friendly people left, favourable discount
cons:
- If you’re a product person who is coming to do ‘product’, you’re in for a shock.
- Very poor Senior Leadership, even more so in the Product sphere. There’s little direction or vision that makes sense. There’s no Product principles, process or culture. 
- Weak career development, success and moving up is a politics game. If you want to do right by the customer and not follow leaderships opinion, you can be moved teams and put on awful projects until you’re pushed out. 
- There’s no focus on the customer, it’s all about pleasing your stakeholders and developing their wish list. During my first weeks, a rather senior leader told me if I didn’t please my stakeholders and make sure they got their wishes, they’d make sure I didn’t last long. 
- Uninspiring projects and features which consist of moving the product as is from an old tech stack to new. In some cases, the new tech is poor and the feature set is reduced and regressed. 
- No sense of togetherness in the product team. This stems from my previous point on leadership. 
- A big sense of dissatisfaction, not just in Product but across the whole company. Not good for mental health. 
- Low salary, nowhere near the industry standard.

headline: Great company on the whole
pros: My experience on the whole has been positive. Berwick in particular has a warm and supportive culture with a fantastic CEO, Richard Love, who really cares about his staff. I can't speak for the rest of Odgers however. The company overall works hard to develop its culture, we have bake sales, whole company assemblies once a week, D&I festivals, extravagant Christmas parties and away days. The company has dealt with the pandemic well, particularly in how it has handled working from home and the promise to maintain this flexibility in the future. There has not been any pressure applied to return to the office, the approach from the SLT has been very human and caring throughout. Cannon St office is in a brilliant location. Work life balance is very much respected, very rarely do I have to work out of hours and am not expected to take my work home with me.
cons: There is a sense of inequality and hierarchy at times between support staff and fee earning staff that is not malicious, just ingrained into the culture within some of the longer standing members of staff. The company is also trying to catch up when it comes to D&I but isn't currently providing any financial backing to this and is instead mostly relying on an employee driven D&I programme. The company has a reputation for being old fashioned and right wing and doesn't do enough to dispel this image, the board and trustees in particular are very outdated in their ideas and opinions. Cannon St office interiors could do with a bit of modernising but it's not a priority now the majority of the workforce are working from home.

headline: Awful culture
pros:
- good for new grads with no experience 
- good starting salary for grads 
- some interesting projects available (although these are few and far between)
cons:
- performance process is flawed and biased. Based solely on your network and who you know. Very little of your actual performance or feedback from direct line managers taken into account. Building your  ‘personal brand’ is the primary concern of the company from day one, which encourages people to cosy up to management who will help them through promotion, rather than focussing on building up useful skills. 
- incredibly competitive and toxic culture, particularly in ACG. To be expected when you are ranked against one another during performance review 
- analysts have no say in shaping their career - schedulers and management only care about charge-ability.  If you turn down unsuitable roles you will be penalised. 
- analysts are taken advantage of by senior staff eg forced to work on clients without a chargeable code, which is then used against them at performance review 
- questionable management of the recent redundancy process - Accenture now having to rehire multiple roles, no senior management pay cuts etc 
- it looks bad to be throwing countless freebies at your employees whilst laying off 6% of the UK workforce 
- on paper, great policies regarding valuing the individual - yet to see this translate into the culture

headline: Misleading Job Description
pros:
The culture is honestly amazing. I joined during a pandemic as well so that's a pretty big statement considering I never went to the office. You'll feel supported and everyone is really friendly (including partners).
Great work life balance.
cons:
The risk advisory position I took in Technology Digital Risk was mis sold. It is essentially IT Audit, with the 'chance' of doing advisory work 5+ years down the line if you're lucky (note its about an 80/20 split between IT audit and advisory work anyway). I doubt the advisory work is interesting and worth 5 years of your career regardless.
No career progression outside of the firm. If you stay long enough, you'll only get Internal Audit opportunities at mid and big size firms. It pigeon-holes you completely.
As a reference point, a few other grads reached out to me when they heard I was leaving as they were all feeling the same way about the job - seems like everyone is duped into this role in a way.

headline: Good company, bad management
pros: Good people, fair pay, training courses available
cons:
Poor staff retention rate in the procurement team and when you get inside you start to understand why there were so many people before you and none of them lasted. 
Constantly badmouthing people behind their backs like it's something normal. 
Combo of crazy workload and double-faced, toxic management who seems to enjoy people's failures and mistakes.
Boys club.

headline: Major cost cutting and sell sell sell bank.
pros: Cant think of any to be honest.
cons:
Customers verbally abuse you and then management does nothing about it because the customer has multiple accounts.
Pointless staff engagement survey where you are watched by local management when completing because everything is hunky dory isnt it. 
Mountain out of a molehill when you make a very minor mistake. One time first ever major mistake and your out the door.
Favouritism is rife.. you are not promoted based on skill its based on who you play golf with or what football team you follow.
Micromanaged to the extreme and staff are frightened to speak out because they are then made out to be the problem.
Cost cutting to the extreme to the point nothing is being invested in. Broken computers and printers for past year, keyboards don't work. Cashier machines failing at least twice a day. The IT systems the bank uses to pay in money fail every day. Money is wasted and thrown at contractors.

headline: Good work life balance but poor pay and progression opportunities.
pros: Good work life balance with flexible working hours. Understanding and supportive management for the most part. Responsibility for your own work can gives a great sense of achievement.
cons:
Progression opportunities in technical tax fields severely limited outside of the inspector training program (TSP). Program is only open for applications once a year to start the following year, there is no advantage for internal staff over external and success is based on assessment centre performance rather than qualification and or/experience.
As a result many experienced staff either stay underpaid at lower grades becoming frustrated or leave to work in private firms where their experience is valued and rewarded. 
There is also poor representation of minorities in senior grades for a department that is very diverse.

headline: Great Staff- visible upstairs/downstairs divide.

6 years of blood, sweat, and mostly tears, may even get you a permanent badge. Oh lucky you! 
If/when you move to corporate, there is no going back. They will not take you back for your previous position. You're not wanted anymore. 
Corporate are mean. No patience when it comes to training. 
There's a lot of favouritism. 
Hard work goes unnoticed.

headline: Really good place to work, good work-life balance
pros:
Fast paced, challenging tasks (the company is not for you if you prefer the same day-to-day routine), you feel you have a voice and they value your opinion. Access has really good managers in my opinion, you are encouraged to learn and develop yourself and you definitely have people to learn from. (good mentoring, coaching program, lots of opportunities to develop further in your role)
Good work-life balance, options for flexible work, (though the new office in Loughborough is going to be really nice)
Good decisions are being made for the future of the company, I feel the company reacted well for Covid, retained or retrained staff, supported employees with during lockdown, adapted sales strategies , supported customers and didn't take advantage of the furlough scheme.
cons:
Fast paced working environment, you need to be adaptable to quick changes, accept that what you worked on last week might have to be changed or dropped the next and focus on other priorities.
There are periods when you have to put in evening or weekend work but your efforts are recognized.

headline: Really enjoyable experience

You get training on an app from every brand you work for and then also go out to conferences and specific brand training to help teach you about the brand and help with how to provide the best service. You also get allocation every three months where you get to choose some products to try (the amount you get to spend depends on your hours) as this is part of your uniform. You also tend to get free products from training.
cons: Honestly just the typical things in any job. You get tired on your feet all day but if you make yourself busy you can’t have a bad day

headline: BT hanging on by a thread due to monopolistic position
pros:
Good work-life balance
Generally quite a good group of people
cons:
Legacy systems - plethora of old and useless IT systems that stop anything from launching
Bureacracy - lack of clear processes and no clear boundaries/frameworks for decision making make it a nightmare to get anything done
Adverse to change - colleagues who have been here for 5+ years are often blockers to any initiatives
Extremely poor salary progression - complete disregard for market pay levels, with internal moves often only providing 5% pay rises
No clear career progression - vague career levels mean it is almost impossible to work your way up the ladder
Lots of lip service from Directors and above - selfish and only concerned about their own welfare
HR - huge amount of ownership on everything, with little regard for practicalities and market movements

location: Salford, North West England, England, England
headline: Image-obsessed management, only concerned with lining their own pockets
pros: Great fellow team members, who became a supportive family through the stressful and often downtrodden atmosphere
cons:
- AJ Bell like to hire youngsters fresh out of uni or from their first job at a shoe shop with no financial experience. This combined with the ridiculously high turn over of staff means no-one ever knows what they're doing, mistakes are constantly made and the workload piles up for the few experienced staff members to have to deal with.
- AJ Bell ensure that you can only progress if you are having marital relations with one of the managers, or if they want to have marital relations with you. Hard work is not recognised or appreciated.
- It seems that bullying is widely accepted throughout the company as the HR team have absolutely no power or purpose. If an anonymous complaint is made about a particular manager then it will always get back to them & make the situation worse. There are no consequences to their actions until the bullied staff member decides they have no option but to leave.
- The directors only care about lining their pockets and company image to protect their share prices - there is such a huge push every year to ensure the company survey helps them reach the Times top 100 company list, and if staff members leave bad reviews then their Team Leaders are punished by having their annual bonus taken away.
- Despite the compulsory staff attended biannual meetings the Director holds to boast of the sheer increase of growth and profits, pay rises were denied in 2020 for the majority of staff (aside from upper management).

headline: It is what you make of it
pros:
Relatively secure job and flexible working arrangements. Equiniti has been fantastic throughout the COVID period. No redundancies or pay cuts as far as I'm aware. 

If you have a good relationship with senior management, you have the opportunity to move between different divisions, try new job roles and progress quickly within the company. 

Equiniti is making an effort to keep staff healthy and motivated with mindfulness and mental health sessions, fitness challenges and started a working from home hub where teams can share recipes, home schooling tips and other information.
cons:
Weak business model and a lack of investment in platforms and products has hindered innovation and development. There seems to be an acceptance of legacy IT systems and processes that have impacted both individual and business-level efficiency.

The acquisition of companies over the years appears to have clouded Equiniti's focus and has led to funding being stretched thinly across numerous divisions. 

While many of the senior management team and directors are competent and able, some have been at the company since the start of their careers and have relatively little experience and, or, minimal qualifications compared to peers at comparable organisations. Nice to see people climbing the ranks but worth keeping on top of the market and seeing whether external candidates could bring more to the role.

headline: Strong stable innovative company company but a bit political

cons:
Plenty of office politics and other politics as well. The company has recently gone quite political ( you really have to be on with the whole climate-change thing or try and shut it out.)

headline: Reassured changed my life!
pros:
I have worked for Reassured for almost 2 years. To say that my life has improved significantly since joining, would be something of an understatement!
The salary and bonus scheme are amazing, however Reassured's biggest shining stars are the management team and the staff. Never have I felt such a sense of belonging to a company as I have at Reassured. The team here have supported me through one of the most difficult periods of my life and continue to help me grow and develop, always pushing me to be the best I can. I really cannot recommend Reassured enough. Thank you!
cons: There is never any milk in the fridge on a Monday morning, and I need my coffee to survive!!!! Jokes aside though, there is nothing I would change (except for more milk).

headline: Great culture and colleagues
pros:
Company benefits are great. You get access to online learning materials including Udemy, LinkedIn Learning etc. 
A great pension scheme, weekly free fruit and lunch vouchers to selected eateries nearby, Freaky Friday (monthly social with complimentary drinks and food). 
People are lovely and approachable. You create a lot of special friendships with many of your colleagues.
cons:
The salary could have been better for the location you live in (London is very expensive). 

They were not open-minded to people working from home (prior to COVID, you would have to have a really good reason to have to work from home for one day) – their way of thinking may change now that working from home during a pandemic is the was forwards for companies.

Not much career opportunities when you work in a local office. All of the good roles are in HQ based in Amsterdam, so you need to be open to moving there is you wish to progress in the company.

headline: Fantastic Company

I joined Access over a year ago after leaving another business of 20 years and never looked back.
The business has fantastic benefits, such as holidays, Staff Share Scheme, Bonus, Staff day where the Access teams come together and celebrate success.
Everyone that I interact with are supportive and always willing to help you develop and grow as such feel this a a real genuine business that really cares and confides in their people. As an added bonus for me my reporting manager is one the most genuine considerable people I have ever met and is a real joy to work for them
I am extremely proud to be part of the Access Group.

You are implicitly rewarded by the constant carrot dangling of promotion rather than salary increases/bonuses in your current role.

headline: Great people, but very hierarchical  company and management
pros: Great colleagues, the best people I have ever meat with.
cons:
The company is stuck in the 1980s structure wise. Procedures are very harsh and non personal. They don't have much career progression incentives. You almost feel like you will have to work for the company for 20year and retire with the same salary. You are only listened to if you know someone in a high position in HO, otherwise you are told to be happy that you have a job. They are trying to progress but structurally they are so fare behind that it will take them about 20years to get there.
The pay is very low as well.

headline: NHS Nurse
pros:

Will massively develop your interpersonal skills and working with a multidisciplinary team.

cons:
Wage is low for the demand of work and stress expected of you.
Career progression might be slow depending on the competition in your area/specialty. 
No free parking for NHS staff

headline: Avoid at all costs.
pros:
Decent pay compared to other leisure centres.
Because management is awful, you form good bonds with other staff.
cons:
Management is terrible.
You will not be valued.
You will be wearing many hats as they dont employ regular cleaners.
You will take the blame for everything from customers as managers will not want to deal with customers.
The moment you get a decent manager, they will be sent to a new centre to open that centre.
When a senior recreation assistant isnt in work, you will take their responsibility with no extra pay to reflect the responsibilities.
When you have a legitimate concern for safety, your reports to management will be ignored.

headline: Good spring board for your career
pros: Good start to your career - you'll be able to learn a lot about the multi-asset investment industry. Also my experience of being in a growth-focused team allow me to spend resources on R&D other than simply churning the standard client deliverables. Company cultures are all friendly and laid-back, and in some way pushing people too hard can be given some proper side-eye. Work life balance is perfect. You have full flexibility over your own working hour as long as you deliver in time and your individual work can fit well with the overall picture.
cons: At early-mid level the work/pay progression can be a joke, and the financial growth of the team doesn't necessarily come down to low/mid level at all, which actually loses the encouragement to the employees that actually generate the revenue. The company also relies quite significantly on existing client-relationship and human factor, and often slow to adapt to industry trends.

headline: Decent Workplace
pros: Flexible working hours that the managers strictly stick to so you never get shifts outside your working pattern. Friendly mix of staff, everyone seems to get along and you actually meet some pretty amazing people. Lots of different backgrounds and cultures of your workmates so there's always people to talk to and learn about. Actual good progression scheme for anyone who does want to maybe expand into managerial roles - always fair when it comes to choosing who to progress.
cons: Customers... as always. You get a lot of stick from customers whilst working there but I mean it's pretty expected nowadays. Managers will always stick up for you thought. Must have a strong backbone to work there I suppose.

headline: Average overall - nice people and friendly atmosphere but one to avoid if hoping to develop or progress in your career.
pros:
- Friendly workforce in general 
- Work life balance is mostly manageable
cons:
- High turnover of mid level staff due to persistent mis-selling of roles. Most arrive to find they have taken a significant backwards step in their career. 
- Junior staff typically don’t stay long given most are overqualified for the admin work they are tasked with. Longer service tends to be in regional offices with fewer competitors locally.
- Salary below market and influenced by myriad of other departments, from NY HQ down.
- Business model and revenue likely to be threatened as technology and data advancements continue, could be left behind as competitors improve. Reliance on existing client base.

headline: Too slow with change and keeping up with industry pay.
pros: 20% Staff Discount, Sharesave scheme, Tech4Home scheme, Paid in advance, Head of Business Service Centre is absolutely brilliant at looking after employees, make you feel part of a family in head office roles.
cons: Poor support for graduates in retail, very political and often bullying in store from higher management, horrendous sparks loyalty scheme, no overtime, progression is difficult when roles are split between London and Manchester, slow to act on automating manual tasks. Despite no pay rise last year and yet to announce this years pay increase, there are expectations for everyone to lose out on income to come back into the office 3 days a week, very little consideration for those who have come into financial difficulty during the pandemic, also it's a clear way to save money by reducing office space but instead the cost of travel and food will hit employees harder.

headline: Good employer, many opportunities and relaxed culture
pros:
No targets 
Relaxed dress code (there is none) 
Managers supportive and respectful
Good IT (surface pro) 
Work from home
Flexi time - work whatever hours suit you between 7am-7pm 
No unpaid overtime
Great civil service pension, defined benefit which is rare outside public sector now. Employer contribution is about 29% for your 5.45% contribution.
Lots of opportunities to do extra bits for interest, and many opportunities for promotion, I applied and was promoted after 1 year and 3 months
cons:
Organisation is slow moving
Other people in lower paid jobs often don’t have such a positive experience, it depends on your team and grade sometimes. Above O/HO grade people have a better experience in my view, more freedom and autonomy.
Holiday allowance isn’t as good as other civil service departments, only 22 days in year 1, rising to 25 after a year

headline: Some brilliant people and good intentions in an organisation that's ultimately about the bottom line above all else.
pros:
Talented people who pull together as a team.
Enormous organisation (c.60,000) with opportunities to work on high profile contracts in a range of sectors.
Particularly strong in the Government Services and Customer Contact divisions. 
Great vision for where they are trying to go.
cons:
When push comes to shove, they will put profit above anything, including staff welfare. 
Some great initiatives around diversity and wellbeing have been scaled back or sidelined when times are tough. They talk a great talk, but employees' lived experiences, especially out in the divisions, don't match the corporate message. 
Lots of old school attitudes and unconscious bias, especially at middle-management level. 
They don't learn from their mistakes - no group-wide 'lessons learned' or continuous improvement, especially in HR where every restructure/redundancy exercise is handled terribly, but they repeat the same mistakes!

headline: Okay
pros: Prestige. Outsiders worship its reputation
cons:
-Training is not in depth and thorough, leaving entitled graduates failed to equip key techniques and concepts, so as to stand on their feet once landing in a job, based on my experience in the program studied
- Among the rotation to different labs, some do not welcome students in my and my programmate case. Also, the rotation is unstructured and the quality of training you received varies from lab to lab. Some not able to pinpoint what techniques you will learn in such rotation. Some not able to set a clear project before taking a student. Labs should be taken out from the list of rotation given to student if they do not have the personnel/ project given. It could be a waste of time. One should be very careful when you meet your potential PI and supervisor, even though things may not be seen within such short and brief period of time. Also, please talk to your programmates or graduates, who have rotated to the labs you are of interested. The representatives or program director is likely to have some connections with them.

headline: Terrible place to work
pros: Pay is decent except no overtime rate.
cons:
So firstly they lied to most people who joined within the first year of the RDC opening during interviews as they told most of us things like we would be working 1 weekend in 4 (you actually work 3 weekends in 4). We were told we get a £1 a year pay rise and we are currently getting 40p a year which is now capped after 3 years at £10.50 (new starters reach £10.50 in a year now). We were told we get lots of benefits like cheaper contracts with EE and cinema tickets which was a lie.

The place is also run by senior managers who want nothing to do with warehouse staff and care only about productivity and not staff health or wellbeing. Below them are the ATMs who are so stressed due to senior management that they often take it out on warehouse staff and charge hands. The charge hands (which no longer even get £1 extra an hour) are dropping like flies and stepping down so quickly that they are forced to continue to do the charge hand role and are on the verge of mental break downs until they can convince some gullible sap to replace them and be a whipping boy for managers for no extra pay.

HR and recruitment are always scratching their heads and asking how they can improve the absolutely shocking staff turnover they have but don't seem to notice that the warehouse management seem to like the staff turnover as it is easier to convince new starters to work stupidly quick to achieve non existent progression. 

Injured at work and not your fault? Better hope you have sick days left because they aren't going to pay you and you'll need to get a union or solicitor involved to put in a claim to recoup lost wages. Also they have a tendency to lie to the council to make any accident seem like your fault to avoid guilt and then make you chase your own tail for cctv footage.

The rota patterns are terrible and always have been. Old pattern involved us working 7 days in a row sometimes with only one day off. Now we have working weeks of 5 days in, 1 day off, 4 days in, 1 day off f then another 5 days in. It kills you! And they still expect you to maintain a high performance target! 

Performing well or quickly means nothing to these people. You work harder they raise your targets. Meet those targets and they raise them again and will keep raising them until you can't achieve their targets then they will threaten you with disciplinary actions to push you to kill yourself attempting to hit their target or it pushes you to leave. You also won't get anywhere in the company by working harder as it seems to be if your face fits and not performance. Slow lazy people get easier jobs so they don't hurt their performance figures and certain people regardless of performance barely have to do any work. 

If you want to work here be prepared to be transported back to your schools days of being told of by your headmaster as that's how they treat you. Like a child.

headline: It's Just Retail with Lego built around it.
pros:
Albeit pricey, the product is stimulating, educational and high-quality and always a pleasure to sell. As a fan of Lego all my life, I felt no shame or discomfort making sales. Lego is something you can happily recommend to others so long as they can afford it.

The store generally attracts open-minded and fun potential employees and customers. You'll find yourself making good friends there with the sales associates and regular customers.

You will gain a lot of self-confidence here. Whilst the job role of always having to put on a big smile and a circus-act can seem unfitting and annoying at times to your personality, you really see that happiness reflected in the eyes and faces of customers and it does make your day. 

Hey, the employee discount is pretty nice.
cons:
As the headline suggests, it's just retail. Having to deal with Lego and friendly customers pacifies your experience and makes it bearable. 

Pay is low, not that there's anything much to expect out of a sales associate in retail. 

You will be berated by managers and supervisors over minor issues. You leave and begin shifts in fear, paranoid you've done something wrong. 

You will turn up to shifts only to have managers tell you in a briefing that 'it's your fault that we're not meeting unrealistic sales numbers'.

You aren't allowed to talk with fellow sales associates on the shop floor. No really, not even five seconds of it. Managers and assistant managers will come running to get their buzz out of berating you for it.

Managers live in fear of senior management/corporate and only push the blame down on to you. It's quite laughable when you're told to be on your 'best behaviour' because Senior Management is visiting, and when they do arrive, just based on first-impressions, they're nothing to write home about. As I said, systems of fear.

NPS system which rates you based on the reviews from customer survey feedback (the link on their receipt). A system which is already inaccessible, inconvenient and meaningless to most customers actually determines how your managers review your performance. So you need to beg customers to fill it out at the till otherwise it would 'seem' as if you're not even doing your job correctly. Surely the managers should be able to assess your performance with their own eyes and ears on the shop floor. 

You'll have to do an hour of 'greet' at the door every shift which is outdated and mind-numbing. Admittedly, having been greeted before, I can understand why it sets a good mood, but it really isn't a necessity and can really drive down the mental wellbeing of your staff on their shifts.

Delivery shifts are tiring and set unrealistic targets. Sadly it's the only time you'll get to be social as it's all mostly back-of-house.  

As with most retail stores, the music choice is terrible.

I do often feel nostalgic about working there, but I only realise now that I just miss the friends I made. I am glad to be away from everything else. As for the Lego bit, I can enjoy that from the warmth of my own home.

headline: Lacks diversity and integrity
pros:
1. People are generally supportive, does not carry the ego badge the Big four firms carry.

2. Good variety of clients to work and learn from.
cons:
1. Partner decisions aren't great. Chopping and changing of strategy. Warn to hit the bottom line at all costs is the driver despite some clever PR strategies to say otherwise. 

2. Poor performance of staff is not held accountable if you work for the right people. Performance moderation meetings are white washed for favourites. 

4. Not many non-White partners, one of the lowest amongst the big four. Opportunities not given to rise. 

5. HR have no real impact on the business. No drive for change, inclusion and cultural shift.

You will almost certainly be strung along on a fixed-term contract, not knowing whether it will be extended until within days of your end date.
Terrible IT - no dedicated IT staff in offices.
Performance is not rewarded, so most staff barely strive to meet the minimum requirements.
Very little prospect of advancement outside of surveying.

headline: Caring and inspiring company with great culture but limited opportunities for senior progression

- amazing culture, you feel your work makes a difference 
- great leadership, some fantastic directors that are really inspiring that have recently joined and are shaking things up and getting exciting projects delivered 
- flexible working opportunities for parents
- incredible support delivered to members and patients through COVID with old slow processes gone and a new way of thinking emerging
- fantastic people and great working environment even when remote
cons:
- Limited career progression, few senior manager or head of positions so encouraged to take sideways moves 
- secondment culture 
- maternity benefits and culture need improving 
- can be risk averse (though COVID has changed the way Bupa has been thinking)

headline: Flexible, remote work with a completely disorganised company
pros:
Can work remotely from home, in which case, hours tend to be flexible. 
Tend to get repeat / long-term clients.
The variety in topics you cover can be interesting (e.g. working with students and staff from different subjects).
cons:
Sometimes no work in-between University years (i.e. summer months).
The company can be very unresponsive, which gets very frustrating.
The company does not supply you with any software to make your work easier.
Often, they don't even tell you what the pay is for different clients.
They ask you to state which subjects you don't want to work with (i.e. specialist subjects like the Sciences), and then completely ignore what you say.

headline: Looking back
pros:
After 35 years with Sainsburys I believe that it is a company I have loved working for. If you are flexible in both role and where in the country you work there is opportunities to progress.
They are a company that does live its values and although it sometimes makes mistakes it learns and is better the next time.
I believe the package offered for management is good for a retail company.
cons:
As with most companies there are times when to progress your face needs to fit. However normally you can move if it is a clash with your manager as long as flexible.
The other con for me is the potential working hours. As a company feeding the nation it means you have to be available when the customer wants which means a requirement for shift work including week and Bank Holidays

- Absolutely horrendous supervisor, whom in my time working for Newquay Specsavers branch, I had seen her bully at least 3 different employees (some of which were loyal employees, working at the store for 7+ years) until I too had succumbed to the vile grip of this particular person. This supervisor is a sly individual, at face value, looks as though is a pleasant person but behind your back, will speak nasty of you (NO ONE IS SAFE - TRUST ME) Very manipulative, and likes to use her "power" and experience against you and applies the 'one rule for you, another rule for me' move with all. 
-Said Supervisor has also leaked very personal and sensitive information to employees about an emplyee which is against policy and completely wrong in all ways. 
-Expects you to be at the store 30 mins before and sometimes over an hour after the store shuts without pay. 
- A lot of Favouritism and Work politics (Don't say I didn't warn you)
- If you'd like a good reference once you eventually leave the company (I'd be surprised if you stay longer than 6 months but if you do, power to you brother/sister) 
don't even bother requesting from them... unless you end up somehow in their good book, part of their gang. 
- Don't trust anyone... 
- If you want to cry at least once a month, this is the place for you 
- Pay is a joke for the work and things you have to put up with 
- Training opportunity is laughable, what training?
-You want to work your way up in the company? Good luck. 
- 
All I've got to say is, most jobs have their downside but with a good team and with good people it is easier to bare and can you overcome the issue together but trust me when I say, It all starts with the people you work with, In my experience, this is the worst company branch I have worked for.

headline: A tough environment!
pros: There are some genuinely lovely people working at Capita who will go out of their way to help and welcome.
cons: An organisation that is still driven by the finance team despite changes in leadership and Exec. Their is no autonomy for managers to manage or make decisions, even senior leaders who should be able to manage own budgets, hiring etc... You are a number at Capita, their is very little employee advocacy and nothing is done to address this. Despite a Chief People Officer being in post this does not filter down across the business. I would say majority of people at Capita are their to earn a living not to build a career as the business is so disjointed everything is hard, processes you would expect to be simple and straightforward are unnecessarily complex and until they address this they will always have financial challenges, the wastage is unreal!

headline: Culture eats strategy for lunch
pros:
Best company I've ever worked for. It's amazing to be part of a company that managed to grow in a super fast-paced without compromising its values and culture. It seems like everyone is always walking in the same direction towards the same goals - we are truly obsessed with customer success. "Your success is our success" is not just a generic moto written in the walls to keep people motivated, but what's demanded from each and everyone of us every single day. 
No easy for company with 50k+ employees to have such a great alignment. And it's true, maybe there will be some misalignments here and there, but all in all, I can just say how proud I am to work for a company that appreciates such noble values. 
Onboarding is overwhelming - specially if you're in a sales position, but the opportunity to connect with great people, learn from the best professionals in the industry through a structured enablement methodology is a great privilege. 
As any sales department, people will fight over deals or accounts, but Salesforce has taught it all: processes have been put in place to avoid conflicts and make disputes easier and fair. 
When it comes to innovation, it's literally at the center of everything we do. Salesforce is always 10 steps ahead of the market, planning the next tech hit or next move.
cons:
Remote onboarding takes a bit of the excitement of exploring Salesforce, feeling welcomed and connecting with colleagues.
New hires may feel it's too much information and too many things to digest in a short period of time. Trailheads, Astro Courses and Online Sessions can be very exhausting and too theoretical. Having AEs, Managers and colleagues sharing real-life experiences in a fire-side chat can be a great way to learn new things and practice some of the concepts discussed.

cons: It's a shame that commission structures are much lower than where they should be, in comparison to most. headline: The most regressive, bureaucratic, and disorganised employer I have ever worked for
pros:
Good pension but we're going to be working until we're dead so...
Flexible shifts, staff benefits are competitive compared to other companies, stable job
cons:
Where to start... it took 9 months from being accepted for the job to actually starting the job, the recruitment process was a total joke it was so slow and inefficient; recruitment appointments were spaced months apart when I could have done it all in one week. They refused to pay me 50 hours of mandatory training because it was completed more than 3 months ago?? (despite being told before I signed the contract that they would pay me for all mandatory training I completed). What sort of rule is that? I mean it's not as if they need nurses anyway is it.


Inefficient systems and the computer software often crash and does not save data, so you must repeat the task, reported to IT months ago and still no improvement. Decisions by management concerning employees is about following rules rather than using common sense or just doing the ethically right thing. So disorganised and disjointed it is a total nightmare trying to get anywhere, employees are treated like a disposable workforce

headline: Do Not Work Here

headline: Covid
pros:
Staff and kind and friendly on a personal level.

Flexible hours (but lots of them)
cons:
We are massively behind the other firms in terms of work from home and technology. The start of the pandemic was particularly difficult as we have never been allowed to work from home before and there is not enough equipment to support all staff.

There is no flexibility with studying for students, they are expected to teach themselves, work 50+ hour weeks and then pass exams that you’re sitting from home. It’s inflexible and demotivating and has resulted in lots of students leaving for the big 4.

Lots of senior recruitment which stops more junior staff progressing

headline: Stay away
pros: The salary is quite good for such an entry job
cons:
I worked within the SUMMIT study and the management team was just completely horrible. Complete lack of communication regarding serious matters. They only allowed us to work from home 2 weeks after the announcement of the 2nd lockdown. And even then, it didn't come directly from the management team, but rather through other people. They also didn't provide any equipment to allow us to carry our work from home. So I had to use my own laptop, my own printer, my own headset etc. The management team don't care about the team, especially those at lower levels then them - they rather throw at them all the work they can't be asked to do. 
Additionally, they advertised new positions externally, rather than internally, knowing that the majority of CTA team wanted the new positions.

headline: Don't bother
pros: A lot of independent work with authors which can be rewarding as you build up a rapport; kind and very knowledgeable colleagues.
cons:
Frankly shocking levels of performativism when it comes to caring about mental health e.g. given a "mental health day" once per year, but doing nothing of value to assist employees with ludicrously high workloads even when they raise concerns about stress affecting their health. 
Pride themselves on equality when this is not reflected in the hierarchy - pretty insulting. 
Career growth is non-existent (unless you're at the very top).
Work-life balance might be okay in the first half of the year but you can wave goodbye to idea of a weekend in the last half of the year. 
Woeful levels of honesty and transparency from managers and those in senior leadership positions. 
Performance reviews are a farce.
If you're an editor who cares about the work you produce - don't bother applying because you won't be given the time to actually ensure its up to a decent standard.

headline: They went downhill quickly
pros:
It’s nice to speak to lots of different people. Sick pay after probation, and maternity pay after a year are better than what the government give you. 
The discount card is good but things that aren’t boots are generally cheaper elsewhere.
cons:
Managers are usually where they are as they’re massive suck ups, gladly they had a big cull lately, some are genuinely nice but they move on quick.
No development given for regular guys unless you beg and nag for it.
Customers can be rude and demand things and you’re expected to take it, they moan and get everything for free.
If someone gets Covid in your practice you’re expected to carry on as it’s ‘Covid secure’ though they don’t take the PPE rooms where you all change together or the staff rooms and back areas where everyone walks around without a mask talking, into account. They’ve probably all had it and been spreading it around.
Uniforms are horrible.
Optometrists can do whatever they want especially long serving ones and you’re supposed to pick up the abuse for them running late/putting in late holidays requests which are granted/having to rearrange the clinic due to the customers booking with the call centre who are awful and have no idea what they’re doing.
Rotas change constantly so you can’t plan anything, manager gets whatever they want and the rest cover them.

headline: So much wasted potential...
pros:
HQ near Euston Station.
All sites relatively close to each other.
Lots of diverse and specialist services.
Some people at the top of their field and really breaking ground clinically.
cons:
Subliminal Sexism.
Completely riddled with incompetent 3rd Parties / sub-contractors who are 100 percent there to line their own pockets rather than deliver quality services and absolutely getting away with it.
Spends cash like it prints it.
Senior Management very self centred / inward looking with rose tinted glasses. 
Gross over promotion of NHS Grads in the management structure.

headline: Promotion is down to who you drink with more often than not
pros: Some amazing people to work with
cons:
Pay is terrible, pressure is massive, rewards are scarce or kept secret. 

You're efficiently beaten each day with backlogs (which JH are happy with). Teams which get rid of their backlog are thanked by having staff taken away thus putting them into backlog (smart thinking there management). Training has, all the way through my time there been done by whoever is free (even people who've been there for only a few months) and anything can stop training. It's never been important to JH. 
The work timing system, EG isn't kept upto date for changes or timings but can and will be used to beat you down. Team managers do their best and issues are from department managers upwards, they have little understanding of day to day stuff and also have little desire to actually engage with staff. Also if you're thinking that James Hay is a career for you, they are unable or unwilling to promote you very far. You won't make it to top management.

headline: Very easy if you do it right 80% of the time
pros:
Safety is number one priority
Canteen with cheap food
Discount shop for all workers/visiters in the centre
Friendly people are met on a daily basis if you look the right direction
cons:
Depending which role you work you may sometimes have to work your self silly to help tesco and managers stay on top of things like if they fall behind on customer orders anywhere from 0 to 45 unforfilled deliveries out of around 3400 on a daily bases but there has been times with up to 200 or even 900 orders cancelled for different reasons.

Sometimes there is lack of communication when there is something new.

The device which tesco gives us uses an app called "co pilot" is absolutely useless most drivers will agree...the device will freeze or press the back button by itself on a daily basis or you will find destination points to be 0.1-0.5 miles away from the customers address.

headline: Long Term Ex. Employee
pros:
The Digital team are making strong strides to put the customer at the heart of the business. 

Strong emphasis on using data to make decisions

Agile ways of working have been embraced.

Consumer CEO (Marc Allera) is very inspiring. 

Pension is incredible.
cons:
New salary structure / benefits structure introduced in 2019 has lowered salaries and removed benefits such as car allowance.

Some Directors within the business are not open to their own ideas being challenged, especially with regards to team structures.

Can sometimes be an environment where self promotion / personal brand is sometimes seen as more important than actually doing the hard work...

Leadership teams across the business aren't very diverse. However, very diverse up to Senior Manager level.

headline: Tesco Customer Assistant
pros:
Clear job role and requirements. You know what is expected of you and are given the training and tools to perform well in your job. 

Colleague discount on food after 6 months of working at Tesco. 

Fellow colleagues are often friendly and all in all the stores are a nice place to work.
cons: Management often expect too much from colleagues. The checkouts are rarely staffed properly in bigger stores and management refuse to acknowledge the pressure this has on colleagues. Their focus is on saving money by not offering overtime to cover busy hours. Management do not often reward hard work or effort. Company policies are not always made clear from the outset and issues with holiday come as a surprise later.

headline: Third time lucky!
pros: I worked on 2 different desks at Randstad before finding my feet ... 3rd time lucky! My managers never gave up on me, they supported me and gave me multiple opportunities. Once I found my feet on my desk, I ran with it billing £265k in one year. I went on an incentive trip to Marbella, won an award at our annual conference as well as monthly recognition with bottles of Champagne or lunch clubs! The team really care and if you work hard you are rewarded for it.
cons: The company has become more corporate but with that will also come more opportunity.

headline: Wonderful people and really interesting digital projects
pros: Large scale transformative projects to get involved in that are often bank wide in scale with opportunities to collaborate internationally. Really friendly culture. Have really demonstrated putting employee wellbeing at the heart of decision making during the past difficult year. Lots of network groups and focus on creating the best culture possible.
cons: It's too easy to only focus on your own department and you wont be given much of a view on what is happening across other areas of the bank. You need to proactively reach out to people and create a network to make a strong impact.

headline: Window dressing and lip service
pros: You will absolutely be challenged as the mission is a big and complex one. Peers and “doers” in the company are some of the best and brightest I’ve ever worked with, although those talented people are now choosing to leave in their droves to find a place where they will be better appreciated.
cons:
There is a complete disconnect between the teams in commercial, product and engineering resulting in constant internal bickering and “retros” that never see the light of day after they’ve been churned out. They serve no purpose other than to provide fodder for the inevitable witch hunt to identify the “guilty” party in whatever is the latest drama.
The highest turnover of management I’ve ever seen coupled with perpetual re-orgs and inability to stick with any form of strategic direction for longer than a few months has resulted in an organisation pushing and pulling in different, and mostly opposing, directions.
The above, plus many other reasons, results in the constant feeling of having a target on ones back and the thought that anyone will be discarded when they have burnt out and served their purpose.
I am truly sad that I’m writing this as I had high hopes for the company and my place within it. My, and l’m sure many of my colleagues, main reason for sticking it out is the promise of shares, although they appear to be decreasing in their value with each passing day.

headline: Working for FirstPort
pros: The positives that come from working for FP are that I’m part of a community of people that are supportive, friendly, positive and who only ever want the best for each other and the company. FP encourages its employees to excel and grow, its sees talent and potential and gives people the confidence to step outside their comfort zones and give something a go. Over this last year the ‘normal’ way of working has changed and we have had to adapt, but the whole company has pulled together to make it work!
cons: Currently the only cons I feel impact me whilst working for FP is the current climate, that is forcing a change in the way we work. Whilst working from home we aren't able to interact with departments and team members in the way that we were able to whilst working in an office. I do miss seeing my colleagues face to face but we have adapted to modern technology and worked around it!

headline: You need a lot of self esteem and confidence to work here, being competitive is highly encouraged
pros:
SJP offer the opportunity to move roles within the company, should you decide you need a change. The company is full of lovely, hard working and genuine people, the people are what make working here bearable. They used to have a very attractive bonus scheme, which is the main driver in recruitment.

Their approach to mental illness has been very accepting and they have dedicated 'mental health first aiders' who are excellent.
cons:
Bonuses have not paid out to employees on the lower end of the scale (bonuses still paid out to Directors), but this was unexpected and poor results were not communicated properly to staff, until they were informed they would not get a bonus or pay rise.

I would not recommend working here if you are not super-confident, management will happily tell you that you are replaceable and should be grateful for your job. My experience at SJP has been one of manipulation, especially if you feel you are worth more than you are getting treated. Working in the Partner Services division, you are told that 'Partner is King' and you should do anything they ask of you and accept any abuse you might get from them over emails/telephone.

SJP do not value their staff and regularly talk down to their hard-working employees. They do not seem to value the importance of rewarding and recognising hard work, instead expecting it and disciplining anyone who is not giving 110%. 

Unfortunately, I have seen many employees made to feel they could not find a job elsewhere and feel they have to stay. There can also be a very bitter atmosphere for recent Graduates, or people keen to seek out development opportunities, stemming from jealousy or an inability to accept change.

SJP are very old fashioned in their approach, often not accepting new technologies and still being largely paper-based.

headline: An amazing company that makes you feel secure, stable and worthy
pros:
You get a lot of people moaning about how businesses could do better. There is not much more that Hitachi could do better on.
Hitachi really look after its employers , they provide them with a sense of stability and security . I have been through one rescission with Hitachi to which they looked after there employers.
Over the last year the company has shown more than ever that your just not a number but they actually care for peoples mental health - which at times its been needed. They have great bonus schemes - if your in the office there are lots of events and the atmosphere can be a real buzz. Many "wow" moments and lots of laughter.
I am grateful for Robert Gordon for daily/weekly /monthly updating us through unknown times during the covid shut down - great asset to the company .
IT help is constantly available - they do a great job! 
I am proud to say I a work here - over the last 13 years I have been given the same opportunities as my male colleagues. My voice is always listened to.
The support from my manager is second to none.
Chances to progress.
cons:
Training needs to be more thorough for the new starters , as it seems rushed especially customer service .

There are very few cons. I have worked here for 13 years and I would never work somewhere where I was miserable. Its a great company to work for and i am very lucky to be able to do what i do.

headline: Going downhill
pros: If you have a good Business Manager (which I did) you will be supported to achieve your best. You do get some good perks, and you can see the head office team are trying to be better. But a family run company will always have it's quirky ways - like we can only wear certain colours to work which is bizarre to say the least.
cons: Increasingly KPI driven environment, which often turns out to be a tick box exercise, and isnt what gets good results. Also there was so much resistance to people working from home, even though we had the tech to achieve this seamlessly. Forcing us in to offices without any justification, putting people at risk for no reason other than a lack of trust.

headline: There is good and bad everywhere and this is not the worst pace to be
pros:
My immediate team and colleagues and the supportive collaborative teams we work with. 

Came in to this thinking admin was just a step in the door to other things but actually this is an exciting and varied role that gives a good grounding in the publishing processes and constant stretch. 

Some days are of course paperwork heavy but others can be based on helping with publishing project proposals, workflow improvements, training others, or just problem solving.

This role may not lead to that editorial position you hoped for coming in but you might find this is more interesting in the long run.
cons:
Constantly being asked to do more with less people and shifting sands making what was once an enjoyable job now quite stressful. 

As with all things these days job security has disappeared. No matter how hard you work, how many extra hours you do to pull that project off, or how much knowledge you have about the business it is clear that your role will eventually be seen as dispensable &/or easily replaced.

headline: Always about Policy's and not people
pros:
Some people are nice

Some managers are understanding.
cons:
The upper management(those who you don't see) only care about their policy's. They would rather uphold them, then give any benefit to the employees.

Don't care about Covid despite the fact that the building has been shut down for over a week due to it. They continue to play fast and loose with any meaningful restrictions. Again because they are so in love with policies.

Insist that trainees and people just coming off training can't work from home because of reasons they constantly change. To put it bluntly they don't need to. Everything is done online.

Does not pay enough for what your expected to do.

Lack of communication on literally anything. You wont know what to do and you wont know how to access important things because they say they are going to tell you and then just dont .

Tell people who are ill will Coivd symptoms to come in, then they will have a meeting about safety because they are ignorant

headline: A hard time for a good company
pros:
The company does have a very good and well engrained culture of encouraging personal growth and engagement in the partnership and of supporting one another.

The new chairman is especially open and communicative about what is going on and is very hands on often visiting stores to inform action.
cons:
Decreasing resources available means that areas are often understaffed or close to being understaffed which means that while the partnership encourages personal development and training actually finding time to do that without leaving a department in turmoil is quite difficult. 

Its no secret that John Lewis, like other high street retailers, are struggling at the moment and this does mean that the future is quite uncertain throughout the partnership
