headline: Nice company at times but rife with issues
pros:
- Decent benefits such as staff discounts, sample sales, fresh fruit, free lunches (London office only) and summer Fridays. (Can leave at 1pm)- Good place to develop new skills

- Good place to develop new skills if you can keep up with the workload, quite often involved in projects that expose you to new processes and practices outside of your normal area of work, you gain a good understanding of how the whole business works and the impact your area has.

- Great finance team with strong leadership and clearly defined policies and practices.

- Great people to work with overall.

- Flexible working and have been quite solid when it comes to home working.

- City centre based offices (Both Leeds and London), easily accessible and nice environment, open offices, no real fighting over meeting rooms, new equipment (connecting TV to laptop can be a tad finicky)/
cons:
- Terrible habit of senior leadership dictating how something should be built, despite never using/never will use a system, and not involving the people who use this system on a daily basis. In some areas of the business there is a huge gap between the technical and functional (business) team, leading to a lot of wasted time in project meetings. It is extremely difficult to call something out (even when you and several other experts of the system are screaming that X wont work)as it will get brushed aside by more senior staff, they claim challenging something is seen as a positive, but it really does cause issues.

- Remedyforce (shudders is disgust) is used as our primary ticketing system, and is run with an iron-fisted call centre style of management which has led to several issues throughout the systems and processes that are used in Burberry. Employees are judged and rated based on how many calls they miss, the number of cases resolved or re-opened etc, and senior leadership doesnt seem to care about the why, and will just pressure managers and team leaders to simply increase the percentages, quite often this has led to team leads being micromanagers. This has led to little incentive amongst several teams for them to implement permanent fixes, these take a long time and coordination from multiple teams which will not be rewarded because the ticket about it will be out of SLA, whereas you get a solid pat on the back for putting in a quick cheap bandaid fix because the ticket will be in SLA.

- Low salaries that do not meet the industry average couples with the expectation that you should work beyond your remit where there is little reward or recognition for doing so has led to a high turn over for talented staff.

- Employee engagement surveys are the same every year, there is a disconnect between staff and SLT, many feel under appreciated and overworked.

headline: A Lidl Shop of Horrors
pros: There is absolutely nothing nice about working here!!! avoid at all costs!!!
cons:
All the nightmare stories of working in Lidl are true. They overwork you to the extreme. And it is Company wide, happens in every store. Don't work here at all costs!
The work is horrible. There is no respite here you have to run around like a maniac at a million miles an hour doing a million things at once and keep it up for 10 hours shift.
stores are understaffed. Literally 3 people running a store with the same turnover as a large Sainsburys. All so someone above can get richer. Screw that!!
The pay is not great for what they put you through - you have to do the same job as 10 people in any normal supermarket, for only a few pence extra.
The shifts are bad. either 5am till 3pm or 1pm till 11 pm. you will always clock out an hour or so later though because you have so much work to do. breaks area a joke 15 mins if that. colleagues can be nasty aswell, one tried to fight with me in the store because he was jelous that he had to do a different job to me. I can not stress enough how bad a job working in a lidl store is!!!!

headline: Overall it’s a nice place to work but there are issues
pros:
-Generous and supportive in helping people WFH, allowed us to expense office equipment.
-Overall there is a nice, supportive culture that supports D&I. All festivals are acknowledged and celebrated.
-There’s some really talented people within Tech (sadly it is them that are leaving though)
-Holiday allowance is quite flexible
-Great team building activities ( when we were in the office) 
-Generous discount both Sainsbury’s and Argos
-Quite transparent, there’s always comms and Lives and everyone is welcome to ask questions, Senior Leaders don’t shy away from answering questions, even those that are contentious
cons:
-Senior Leadership Team have made some god awful decisions recently 
-Bonus last year was really poor, in fact- it felt like a slap in the face considering we were one of the only businesses to continue to operate as usual
-Diversity and Inclusion can sometimes be a little woolly- we’ve just stopped an entire engineering apprenticeship programme because there wasn’t enough individuals meeting our D&I quota- people should be hired based on their skill sets not to meet a quota. There’s other ways to drive more D&I into the organisation
-Some areas of the Business still work in Silos to tech which make it difficult sometimes to do the right thing, never seems to be noted all challenged in the correct way
-It feels like some Managers are promoted into that role as it’s the only line of progression, this in turn means there are some Managers out there that are aren’t great at People
Management, this can sometimes bring moral down

One day, out of the blue, I recieved a P45 in the mail. No warning, no reason, nothing. I was absolutely devastated. I only worked there for around 6 months, but I had thrown everything into that job and had grown close with both the staff and residents. I feel let down and undervalued by a company at a time when we were all working hard to try and keep our vulnerable residents safe and happy under very difficult circumstances.

headline: Be careful before accepting the offer
pros: Brand image on the CV
cons:
Tailored for Partner's.

You're dreaming if you're expecting to grow financially with them...

You will be expected to do a LOT beyond your customer engagement (up to 20 hours a week and sometimes more) with very little recognition. The joke is that you will hear a lot of music about work life balance...

Huge focus on a single subjectively negative appraisal over 10s of positive client recognized impacts. This will also impact your promotion and salary increase, if it ever happen (hope you will not be shocked with 50£ and 100£ hikes)

If you have an alternative offer, please do not overvalue Deloitte as a brand or company. Never take their offer if it's not better than the competition as you will be squeezed for every single penny you will be getting.

Be very careful with the HR and recruitment team, they are expert MANIPULATORS. They will put every pressure on you to make you feel like you will be losing a lot by no immediately accepting an offer that is not aligned with what you want. The recruitment process might take 9-12 months and they will almost seem to be proud of it, but they will ask you to think over a scrap offer overnight hinting that they have a lot of applicants waiting for the role...

Not aligned to what other consultancies do, You will be expected to pay you lunch, drinks and coffees even if you are travelling to the south pole to deliver a client project.

Don't expect to have the right support to grow. You will be thrown in the middle of the pacific and expected to reach California by yourself. Very poor coaching and average/limited training offering.

Few of my colleagues reported that they have seen a last minute change to the offer bringing the salary and the grade to lower levels while they have been promised that they will be able to get it back in 1 year and as you might be thinking: Dream on; no one of them have been able to get what he expected in day 1 after the 1st year. I came to infer that this is some sort of practice to source high caliber profiler for lower salaries, get them into clients for very high rates (sometime 2 grades higher) while they will never feel that on their salary, promotion or even recognition.

PLEASE, be careful of what choice you're making before joining. I sincerely hope you will not be deeply disappointed and (hate yourself and) regret the day you accepted their offer.

headline: Front Office Stress for Back Office Status
pros: Scale of the company allows you to see how Barclays impacts the community.
cons:
Continual massaging of the figures without investigating the root causes of the anomalies. 
Unequal distribution of budget and status. The Cost Management team did not have a Christmas Party one year whilst Business Managers where always travelling to India etc. 
Coldest company I have worked for. Off shore support are treated as drones. My managers in Radbroke had no interest in my welfare or development. In 2 years, there was no budget to travel up to Cheshire. The first time I met my manager's boss, face to face was when he came down to London to start the redundancy consultation. This was after my manager (who I never met) sent me a cryptic email to be in the office that day. It was disappointing as my manager (despite over 20 years experience at Barclays) ever spoke to me immediately after or during my 3 month notice period. This indicated a lack of courage or compassion.

headline: Good career spring board
pros: Very good in getting varried experience as consulting work is project based and changes a lot. Excellent place to start a career as you can find what you like and what you do not like. There is a strong sense of identity which can be nice if that is what you are looking for.
cons: Despite what Accenture says, obtaining interesting projects is often based on luck. As there is a 0 bench policy, people are encouraged to take whichever project is available. This is not ideal if you want to follow a particular direction. There is also a general expectation to do a lot of extra curriculum activities (read as free work to support more senior people in their sales efforts) to stand "out". Doing one job's well is often not sufficient for promotion. Finally, there is this sense of superiority which can sometimes lead into arrogance.

headline: Great pension, stressful and depressing
pros: Excellent pension they put 27% in ,you put in 5.4%.  It works out around £600 a month. Overtime rate is £22 an hour. After your 8 weeks training, you get a Level 3 Diploma in Custodial care. Would recommend someone young joining the service.
cons:
Most experienced officers have left the service a few years back to cut costs, in effect most officers in service have barely 2 years experience, which is alarming.
I found I was working a wing under staffed more often than not.
Staff facilities were poor or non existent. 
The service in my opinion is been moved to left, or even far left of the political spectrum. 
Dealing with people who have committed self harm and suicide is a horrible experience, working with convicted sex offenders is awful. 
Shift pattern is all over the place, you be working every other weekend.
It's not great money for the job and responsibilities you are charged with.

headline: The world champions of botched SAP implementations
pros: None that I could list.
cons:
While the rest of the company manages its operations on a shoestring, the IT department still believes that "BAT has too much money"; that standpoint drives the whole department behaviour in terms of performance, culture and integrity.

Regarding performance, the vast majority of IT projects fail miserably. When I was working in that department, the joke was that BAT were the world champions of failed SAP projects. The reason is, failure is not seen as an issue in that department, confidence and arrogance are valued much more than competence. And, of course, your ethnicity: woe be to those outside of "CANZUK" + (white) South Africa.

As a result, the culture is based on blaming others for one's own failures, and hijacking your neighbour's successes. People at the top are low-level technicians whose only skill is to relish in abject subservience to their superiors, unable to see the big picture while convinced they are "leaders". Bullies flourish within BAT IT department, and attain the highest positions.

And, as "BAT has too much money", the way vendors are selected and managed is particularly worrying. Again, they are not selected with the business' interests in mind. More expensive, less performing vendors are preferred over more efficient and cheaper ones, even when the choice implies a huge risk to operations. Or useless technologies are purchased to allow the IT "architects" to garner their resumes with that specific skill. Sometimes vendors are selected based on the "cultural fit", meaning the nationality of the vendor - pure Brexit style.

If you have any principle or talent, avoid at all cost.

headline: Great culture
pros:
I worked over 2 years at Bullhorn and left the business with only good memories.
Bullhorn has a great company culture and open door policy. I was given the opportunity to learn from everyone at the company from junior to C-Level
It was inspiring to be surrounded by so many kind and smart people. Everyone helps each other out and pushes everyone to be the best they can be. Sales targets are very realistic and attainable.

I had the luck to work with the best Manager at Bullhorn. She's a power woman who spent the last two years supporting, mentoring and inspiring me every day. Always had my back and never let anyone in her team feel left behind.
cons: Due to the current Covid 19 restrictions it's a shame we can't go to the office, specially on Wednesday for Wednesday lunch

headline: All the tools and technology are here, you have got to be the one to make it happen
pros: The technology is out of this world VS what other recruitment business have access to and this is constantly evolving and developing. The business is also incredibly open minded to allowing you to voice where you want your career path to head towards and will give you the foundation of tools and opportunities for you to go and make it happen. The ongoing training and development has hugely improved in recent years, now offering really great development opportunities for everyone, not just people managers and high billers. We have moved forwards so much in the last 18 months with more autonomy, trust and flexibility as well as a real focus on staff prioritising their psychical and mental well being over everything, which is really refreshing as this was not the case several years ago.
cons: I have to be honest, the pay is not competitive to what other agencies offer. This is not the agency to come to if pay is your only motivator.

Lots of changes for changes sake over the years (such as going 'patchless', which defied all logic) but better of late and much more common sense applied to various approaches to housing management and maintenance. Still need to overhaul repairs in regard to communication with customers (by contractors and maintenance colleagues) as this is somewhat lacking and causes a great deal of dissatisfaction, which then impacts on trying to manage tenancies.

headline: Serious about inclusion & diversity
pros: I've worked at Colt for over 10 years and I love how seriously inclusion and diversity is taken at a senior level and the opportunities for all employees to get involved. Flexible working policies and the support of several great managers has helped me stay working continuously whilst bringing up my children. I also love the Colt Early years programme which has brought so much creative new talent into the company. The culture has changed for the better over the years and I feel like its a really dynamic, inclusive and exciting place to work. Support for employees during lockdown has been brilliant.
cons: Workload per role has always been intense and has worsened over lockdown with so many video calls and emails.

All over the place, lots of restructures all the time throughout the business - no clear vision
The CEO in broadcast told people if you’re happy then leave.
No justification for decisions
Happy to spend on Christmas parties but not to retain staff during a pandemic

Cause stress on staff
Really high staff turn over
All in all poor leadership and an organisation 
Don’t apply

headline: Great colleagues, but no progression and some VERY difficult personalities
pros:
- I have met some great friends working at Net, there are loads of extremely talented and lovely people there.
- Nice office and plenty of space to get a coffee or lunch with friends.
- Handy location in westfields for shopping
- Discount is good, if you can afford it
cons:
- I worked with some truly terrible personalities (real devil wears Prada attitudes), but as long as you are pals with the senior staff (buying managers etc) it literally doesn't matter how terrible or rude you are.
- Progression is extremely difficult, and the buyers always have someone in mind they wanted in the first place - it helps if you are friends with them.
- The amount of people I saw promoted because they had friends in the right places, but weren't actually good at their job was crazy. It also helps if you have loads of money and buy the products (it seems to get people attention and liked).
- The work load was extremely high and I worked late most days (as do most other people in buying and merchandising), because the work load was so high it meant I had no time for progression.

headline: Enjoyable driving and helping but most management are ignorant and hypocritical
pros: Being out on open road is great. Most colleagues and customers are very decent people and its a rewarding job once away from most management. 10% discount is nice. Talking to interesting customers, seeing the countryside and wildlife, helping elderly and disabled people is rewarding. Drivers especially are mainly a really decent bunch and they help each other. Also, you dont have to think much- its easy! So its a great job for a student-easy money and rest your brain.
cons: Wages low and frequently under correct amount. No apologies. By 5th request they often act to rectify. Overloading. Often no time for breaks though deducted from salary. The equipment is terrible: vans breakdown constantly, palm things to scan stuff badly designed. Advice to any new staff: keep an assiduous log of your hours- there will be mistakes and interestingly never in your favour... Dont engage with management as its not worth it....1984...Just keep records, cover your back and enjoy your job

headline: Great Company, Great Benefits & Great Work Life Balance
pros: Been an employee at Citi for 17 years. They are a great company to work for. The investment in remote access has made remote working easy for employees. The work life balance is fantastic. Yes the hours can be long be but there is flexibility from managers.
cons: Pay is not the best compared to competitors. In fact when I did a comparison on Glassdoor against 16 other financial institutions within in London Citi has the lowest average base salary and bonus for a VP which is my grade. Also the prospects of promotion in high cost locations such as London to SVP and higher is almost non-existent. The odd few that do get through are at times somewhat suspect. It appears at times you have to know the right people to move up.

headline: Very exciting place to work

I have recently joined Grant Thornton with a very smooth recruitment process which included visa sponsorship which has been taken care of by GT. The Resourcing Advisor supported me throughout the process with regular updates and answered any questions I had in a friendly manner. 

My colleagues are welcoming and despite onboarding during pandemic and working from home I don’t feel stressed.  

The workload and timetables are well-structured and work accurately which enables the company to perform well. 

The clients I’ve already had a chance to work with respect Grant Thornton and collaborate happily with the audit team. 

I joined Grant Thornton because of the opportunities it offers and the culture I’ve heard really good opinions of and I’m proud and very excited to work for the company.
cons: Have not found any so far

headline: A Great Move
pros:
- Employee benefits have been wonderful (staff shop, discount, canteen / cafe, shares scheme, bonus system and car share scheme...etc!) - Great xmas party too!
-Head Office is friendly and well designed for staff 
- Culture very collaborative 
- Next have been supportive with WFH initiative, overall,
- The clear review (progress / check in system) in place is excellent and allows employees time and space to feel like they'e growing and progressing. 
- Communication across the business is really strong and timely. 
- Good training options 
- Flexible working hours is a huge plus! 
- Engaging internal comms and HQ quite staff environment lead, new building will help also
- Pay scale in place - allows fair and clear pay system
cons:
- Next have been supportive with WFH initiative, however it's quite director lead . 
- Standard holiday is on the lower side of average ( flexible with carry over and buildable over time and you can buy days, which helps)
- Teams very integrated and close (which is a pro, no doubt) however it would be nice for employees to have more regular one to ones for work (not necessarily development lead), than every 6 weeks, even once a month. 
- Although many not in office FT - it would be nice to see Next have more outdoor space for staff to take a break, as quite limited seating / areas.

headline: Stuck in the dark ages
pros:
Individuals within IT Leadership are starting to make a difference
Overall the company culture is good

No enterprise level IT Strategy - very siloed and stuck in old ways of working
Almost everything is built in house which means developers are often stuck working on old technology - deskilling themselves
Immature Project Governance - a tremendous amount of time and money is wasted 
IT Service Management is extremely immature
Culture in IT needs a shake up - PAs still make cups of tea for management!
To progress within IT you must remain technical, most Grade 1s started out in developer roles within the business - therefore they don't have a lot of real world experience.

headline: Culturally sick
pros: Some very nice colleagues with great experience. Culturally truly diverse. Many fee earners were nice and easy to work with.
cons:
Where do I start? 

People in Business Services, particularly in Manchester are under-valued and not appreciated by the management.

Unbelievable favouritism. If you are the management;s favourite, you get away with lot i.e. being late every day and doing little or no work, followed by a promotion. If you are not, you are quickly managed out. namely by using PIPs and other 'tools'.

A lot of time and money is spent on Continuous Improvement with no or little positive result. Courses involved building legos! Come one, this is supposed to be a Magic Circle law firm.

Document production workflow system doesn't work but you can say so. It's all political. Far too much money has been spent on it.

High turnover of staff, many leaving all of a sudden.

headline: Good company culture
pros:
- Collaborative
- Nice people
- Good social events
- Path to progress fairly clear
- International opportunities
cons:
- Discretionary bonus scheme means you often do not know what you'll be taking home until the month of pay day after the last quarter
- Team based profit model means bonuses can often be impacted if team has not had a good quarter (although if you bill £60k+ often they'll make sure you'll be compensated, though anything less than this is unlikely)
- Bonuses are usually around 10%-12% when billing from £60k-£90k - much lower than most agencies

headline: Horrible Place to Work for Minorities
pros:
Lots to work on and a huge opportunity to grow. Relevant if you are only starting out your career.
Mobility is encouraged and surprisingly easy
cons:
Not a meritocracy as advertised - you really only get rewarded when there is a representation up your division leadership chain.
Having lots to work on as a pro is only based on the con of deliberate under staffing.
Non-existent work from home package if you are not on the revenue side. Firm policy has in fine print that you are responsible for all work from home equipment which is ok for temporary one off situations but post covid, there has been zero firm support even when people now have to use personal devices for work full time.
Pipelines are being created for minorities into tech but firm culture is not rapidly changing to improve retention.

headline: Kier Group
pros: I have been employed at Kier Group as an Operations Manager on the Area 4 contract for 5 months now and have found the company extremely professional with supporting me through the recruitment process through the onboarding team. Also being given my role is safety critical I received occupational review and full inductions during my first week. The company ensured all my needs and expectations were met and I found myself accepted as one of the team straight away. The company has me feeling part of the family straight away which I have not felt before in my previous contracts so quickly. If your looking for a professional caring company then Kier is where you belong.
cons: Nothing I have found as a con.

cons:

Salaries are low, capped and employees/ drivers salaries are squeezed whilst managers enjoy large bonuses.

headline: Glass Ceilings abound
pros: Good non-salary benefits, eg great pension, health care and life assurance. Get to work on software highly regarded by the insurance world as best-in-class. Looks good on your CV.
cons: Not had a serious career conversation in 5 years even though I try to instigate them. I have career conversations with my reports and try to foster their ambitions. My own career aspirations feel like an irrelevance. There is also a large problem with nepotism, "an old boys network" - so when senior positions become available, there is no role advertised, and someone just turns up who is now the "head of" something. Later you find out they worked with our business leader at a previous company.

headline: The Perfect Start
pros: Working for FirstPort has been a first class experience from the moment I applied for the position. They are extremely efficient, very approachable and instantly make you feel a part of the team. Receiving a personal email from Nigel, the CEO, welcoming me to the company was a nice touch. I am currently undertaking their extensive 'onboarding' training programme, which is being delivered in a very informative and professional manner and although this is being done remotely due to the current Covid situation, I am gaining a clear understanding of how FirstPort operate and my role/responsibilities. I am sure this will be the start of a long and rewarding career with FirstPort.
cons: None that I am aware of so far

headline: Self-satisfied dinosaurs, unwilling to evolve
pros: You can move around teams and it looks good on your CV
cons:
• They don't really do UX. They are UI-focused and spend most of their time worrying about how things look rather than their function. They refer to UX as 'service design' and refer to UI as UX
• They don't invest in developing their staff and treat designers badly compared to software developers and for that reason were not really user-led
• They don't know how to evolve their online products and test and de-risk assumptions. It's crawling with PMs who'll come to you with legacy assumptions that you have to work around, instead of de-risking

headline: worst empoyer of my life- no matter how desperate you are don't do this to yourself
pros: my colleagues who made working there even bearable
cons: work culture and environment are absolutely toxic, bullying to straight up disgusting behavior from managers and supervisors was the daily norm. if you dared to speak up they made sure you regret it. the circumstances and work conditions there are unbelievable. during the pandemic they forced everybody to go to the office on a daily basis, despite active cases in the office. zero regards for health or wellbeing of their employees while claiming to care about it on company slide shows/mandatory online training. the majority of employees is either devastated by the work conditions and leaves or brown nosing to their manager to avoid worse.

headline: Great Training and Support

cons: It is a tough industry to be starting out in especially given the current Covid situation, you are pushed here so if you want to join any broker here you will have the bets possible shot at success.

headline: BnM store with garden centre
pros: Before I came to work at BnM with Garden Centre, I wasn’t a very confident person and I didn’t like my other job at all. Now, I love my job, Im very happy and love everyone I work with. I actually enjoy coming to work and my managers are both amazing and have always been there for me when I needed them for anything. I have only been there for just over a year and progressed so quickly because of the support I receive from them. Everyday is a challenge which makes it fun. Yes it gets stressful at times when busy but that’s just part and parcel of the job. All the staff are amazing and we all get on so well, a great team. A proper work family.
cons: Just that sometimes it can be a bit difficult to get jobs done in time when really busy but it’s ok.

headline: A Shadow of what it used to be.
pros:
- Previously a brilliant place to work with a wonderful family-esque feel amongst staff in store.

- Previously great benefits.

- Previously a company you could be proud to work for.
cons:
- All competent management were made redundant, instead replacing them with inexperienced individuals.

- Company will find any excuse to not pay you, for example NHS enforced Covid Isolation will not be accepted. You will be pressured to go in regardless of tests.

- Minimal covid safety. Staff made to go in when they should be isolating.

- Overally corporate feel in stores, having spoken to individuals from varying stores most individuals motivation is at an all time low this year.

- Company very obviously value Wealth over Health and do not put colleagues safety first at all.

- You will face an endless amount of abuse from customers due to the company withholding refunds and repairs for months citing Covid as the cause.

- Your job role may change at a moments notice, you may think you are a sales advisor in a customer facing role but you may end up as phone support or 'shoplive'

- 0% chance of progression from sales advisor role, I've known many people to train for years and follow training programs just to be dropped from the program or let down at last moment.

headline: Good culture, excellent work-life balance, interesting work
pros:
Work-life balance: as a government role, one of the only places in the legal profession where it is possible to have a work-life balance . Overtime is rarely required unless working on particularly important projects, e.g. EU Exit or COVID in 2020. Even then, there are now moves to ensure this is properly compensated as opposed to an implied expectation like in private practice. 
Interesting work - the work is intellectually very interesting more often than not. Advisory lawyers often work at the forefront of novel government policy, advising on issues of public and tax law of which those in private practice can only dream. In litigation, lawyers will sometimes lead cases worth £billions. All lawyers are entrusted with a level of responsibility which is likely to be unfamiliar to anyone in private practice at less than partner level.
Culture - in my experience, the department is free from the shallow and superficial culture of most law firms. There is genuinely an acceptance of people for who they are and a tolerance of people from different backgrounds and neurodiversity. There is hugely less pressure to "conform" to a particular personality type (although different teams will inevitably develop their own subcultures to some extent).
Flexible working arrangements - home working is possible up to 40% of the time, which will possibly increase soon to 60%. Many people have bespoke working arrangements around childcare etc. There is no "face-time" culture.
cons:
Uncertain career progression - whilst promotion to Grade 7 remains guaranteed, the same is no longer true for Grade 6 (realistically the highest level most lawyers in government will achieve, unless they are among the few with ambitions to join the SCS). The promotion process relies on the Civil Service Competency Framework, which can be frustratingly vague to those who lack inside knowledge of what sort of answers interviewers are expecting to hear. It also seems to prioritise soft skills rather than legal ability, which results in many highly talented candidates struggling to achieve promotion despite them bringing a lot to the office (though this isn't necessarily that different to most law firms).
Poor office locations (London only) - due to decisions made by an ex-Chancellor decades ago, the main legal UK legal hub on the Strand closes in 2021 and lawyers will be expected to work in Croydon or Stratford once office working. Possibly as a result, there is increasing tolerance of working in other regional locations outside of London.
Pay - has stagnated in real terms since the freeze in 2010. There are signs again this may hopefully change in the very near future.

headline: Manchester Office - Underwhelming, lack of training, mundane processing work
pros:
- Good networking opportunities
- Good central location
- V friendly co workers
cons:
- Really poor wage
-Shocking lack of training, whole grad scheme seems to revolve around networking -which is great but only if used in conjunction with actual training, although probably to be expected from an operating back office. How do you have a grad scheme with no training/pro qualifications?!?!
- High levels of favouritism, overly corporate environment for a place doing processing work and everything done in Manchester office seems to be grossly exaggerated (perhaps trying to impress other locations with more technical roles? Seems they are trying and be something that they aren’t..).
- Also a lot of graduates seem to have probation issues where management try and get rid of them after 6 months, which can be frustrating if they haven’t had any proper sort of training prior! Ironically the grads who want to progress seem to be the ones with probation issues, the ones who are happy to be there are left alone!
- Seems most use BNY Manchester as a stepping stone to go into a better and more technical role somewhere else (not really much scope to move internally). 
- Would recommend prospective grads to look at other locations, BNYM is a great firm but think twice about which office location you are in...

headline: Assistant Manager FS Tech

cons:
- Work/life balance can be poor
- Realistically you are working 40+ hours every week
- You can be stuck on bad projects (particularly for the junior grades)
- Not enough senior positions are held by female or BAME representatives (progress is being made to address this)
- You can't expect to succeed/progress in this business by just doing project work. To be noticed/promoted you have to take on internal work (i.e. sales, thought leadership, proposition building etc.)
- Tough for junior grades to get involved in sales work

headline: Passionate about people!
pros: I believe people are at the heart of this organisation. First Port care about their staff and their residents. They expect the best from their suppliers in order to keep everyone safe. If you want to develop in your role then the hierarchy of management are encouraging and positive in how to help you achieve this. Given the size of the company, the communication is good and the platforms through which you can get information are plenty, which is important as a lone worker.
cons: There are quite a few different platforms and systems to get your head around and understand so it does take time for new starters to get to grips with.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Worked there for over 3 years and like the team I work with. My management are easy to talk to. There is support when needed and a lot of autonomy is given to you when waitressing. There’s always a good friendly atmosphere at work and you get to work in a range of areas from waitressing to expo and bar.
cons:
Hard work is not always rewarded. I work hard and get put on all sorts of shifts over different days. Certain people ring in all the time and get away with it and work wash shifts no weekends. Defiantly can be unfair.
Summer is incredibly busy and often there is not enough staff, this is not necessarily the company’s problem but more an industry problem as people come and go often in these types of jobs.

headline: Hmm
pros:
Flexible
Good pay for the job
Amazing people 
Nice office activities/parties 
Trainings
cons:
The London office was ruled by managers, sleeping around with everybody. You could definitely tell who was appreciated as they’d get a different treatment. In my case I can’t complain but this was clearly not fair. Overall they were still nice...
No real transparency from the Management (Amsterdam).
No real care in the customers in general, the procedure benefits mostly Booking.com, nor the partners, nor the customers! 
Booking.com = money. 
Was also hard to grow within the company as the keep asking you to be as you are (reserved, shy but still good at what you do!) but always ask you to show more in the workplace environment...
The London office is now permanently closed due to COVID. We’ll see in the future.

headline: Please avoid
pros: made great friends who shared equal frustrations with the company
cons:
They forced our group to sign a statement that changed our contract after we had already signed it, asking us to agree to a lower salary after taking the job with the salary stated in the contract. They like to solve issues through personal texts and calling so we can’t log anything they say to cover our own backs - Management are very manipulative. 19 people left out of the 21 people in my training group within 6 weeks.

If you have not experienced anxiety before, trust me you will every day of your shifts. 

They avoided sending contracts for a while, they lied about working hours. I was told I would be given an early shift but to then find out FOUR weeks of working for the company they gave us all 2pm - 10pm FYI they are struggling to fill those slots so if you do receive an offer you will get those hours or similar. They will mention a wish list.... it’d called a wish list for a reason.

They did so many things wrong and unprofessional but I hopefully i’ve said enough to persuade you to avoid this job.

honestly, you are absolutely disgusting and I wish I had taken other jobs I was offered at the time. Complete waste of time, I’m still trying to solve an issue from weeks ago that they avoid addressing unless over texts or a private phone call. disgustingly unprofessional and dodgy.

headline: Uninspiring and ungrateful
pros: Big organisation with lots of different potential jobs to try and skills to acquire. However, it’s very hard to move around.
cons:
Despite everything the BBC tries to say about being a good place to work and helping its staff, it doesn’t care about its employees one bit. The HR dept is completely useless and causes more stress for staff in difficult positions.

There are still managers who bully and have got away with it for years and the pay structure is far from transparent and fair. People get paid more according to how long they’ve worked for the organisation rather than if they’re any good.

Diversity is a joke. I’ve recently seen members of one of the most diverse depts I was aware for made redundant. Decisions are still predominantly made by white, middle-aged men who laugh openly in meetings about things they deem as “working class”, etc.

It’s an extremely frustrating and stressful place to work and it has a long, long way to go to be an acceptable employer for 2021.

headline: Terrible working environment and management
pros: Some great people work there.
cons:
Customer service staff are worked and treated like robots ('robots' is putting it politely) to meet ridiculous sales targets despite not working in a sales role and being in the middle of a global pandemic. 
It feels embarrassing pushing sales of products that customers do not need onto them , when they have called in for help and are telling you how worried they are about their businesses in the current climate. 
The pressure placed is immense with no regard for staff mental health, whilst there are regular 'Your Voice' surveys sent around no change is ever made. The voices of those working with the customer service roles go unheard, when plucking up the courage to speak to management every struggle is dismissed and rather than being supported you are viewed as a problem.
There has been no effort made at all within the customer service job to make things any better for people during the WFH period.
Sage was a much better place when the focus was on actually helping the customer rather than sales, leave that to the sales team.

headline: My Experience has shaped me even more but has left and incredibly bad fast in my mouth
pros:
In some parts a very forward thing company I.e technology 

Colleagues at the lower level are mostly amazing 

Some customers are brilliant to serve
cons:
Social responsibility is non existent when it comes to ethnic minorities. The company’s leadership team at every turn, challenge and opportunity have a shocking appetitive to getting things wrong or just being complicit. 

If fully reflects Britain as it is in the sense that it is the least meritocratic company I’ve ever worked for but it continues to spit out garbage about opportunities. This is evident especially at the higher levels so from level 3 and above, I mean I personally know regional managers vacancies that where advertised but filled after the director personally rang someone to offer them a job without even going through the interview process (nepotism) 

Crabs in the barrel mentality is encouraged immensely by deliberately putting people against each other and not in a healthy competitive manner but almost for sport 

Leadership team aren’t leaders, they are simply managers who micro manage at every stage. They don’t inspire or lead. They don’t trust their colleagues or employees to deliver even though they are the ones that will deliver kpis and objectives.

Lastly, as a leader myself i would sacrifice my interests for the benefit of my team. In Morrison’s almost every leader from store manager level upwards would and in cases were I’ve personally experience sacrifice their colleagues for their own interest and gains

headline: Micromanagement hell
pros:
Most of the people that work on the company are amazing, have even had the opportunity to work with some Amsterdam people - not just the Manchester side and most are very nice people who care deeply for their job.

There's a bunch of perks - terribly badly advertised - which can be used and having a yearly bonus is always a good thing but definitely not enough with remuneration (more on that later). 

The tech you work on can vary wildly, but some of the teams do some very interesting stuff but you may end up working on the legacy parts of the company which I have no description to it other than hell.
cons:
- There is next to no autonomy. Teams don't get to choose what they will focus on, people gets removed and added to the teams like it or not and as a manager I get 0 say over any of it. Managers are there to "report back" but the reality is your opinion doesn't matter unless you're a director or above. 

- Salaries are well below the market average. Engineering Managers are easily 15-20k under market standards, don't get me started about developers. Unless you have newly joined or come with some better negotiating salary so you're good then. Being in the company for more than a year is NOT rewarded. 

- Roadmaps are driven top down. I'm not a product manager but if I was one I would not want to work on this side. I don't know how it works with Amsterdam but in Manchester roadmaps are presented to the team and PMs just have to do whatever they can with it. 

- No manager autonomy (cont). As a manager I can't decide much around my teams, no salaries, no notice periods, hell I sometimes I don't even get to interview people coming into my team. How are you supposed to do anything is beyond me. 

- Even though there's a lot of talk about feedback culture, feedback when applying for internal promotions is next to none and you move up if you know the right people.

Ruined my life and mental health. IT systems not fit for purpose and keep crashing, lack of training and support. Unmanageable workloads due to a high number of students and understaffed departments.

Can be ethnocentric the higher up in the organisation, slight echo chamber around corporate culture and structrual that they remain blind to around diversity.

headline: Dont work here
pros: best pro i found was leaving
cons:
This is the worst job i have ever worked at in my life. The training process was great, Dan young gave me a advert for the great place this will be to work ( i was wrong) Once you're out of the training process another thing which was good was the academy period which lasted around 3 weeks with Dharon Pitt this was also a good advert. Unfortunately this was where it ended and the emotional destruction and, blackmail and micro management started. 

If a phone call comes in and they're not going to renew because they've sold there car so, don't require the insurance, this is your fault, WHY DIDN'T YOU RENEW THEM!! If someone rings through and they've told you twice they don't want to renew, make sure you badger them and harass them and stress the customer out because that's what you're told to do. or when a customer comes through and would like to speak to a manager, good luck trying to find one who can justify why they're paid more and actually take the call over from you, you will be told to say this and say that when really the customer would like to speak to the manager, either way it's your fault for even bothering the manager whilst they have a good catch up about social lives etc. 

When you have your 15 minuet break times don't you dare go 30 seconds over it because this will result in a good talking too and making you feel as though you are a child in school. i understand and appreciate someone being late but this is a new meaning. One thing that is great is the bribery, often when the managers or senior members of the staff need a good review in order to keep there job, they'll bribe you, what with? a Kit-Cat was mine, i was so excited i couldn't wait to write about how awesome the culture and workplace was here! if you renew 15 customers in a row without using any time to breath while standing on your head you earn yourself... a TV? Money? a car? no a celebration (not the box a single celebration) 

If you have any sort of mental health, anxiety, or any emotional imbalance avoid working here as a CR. this will finish you off. They often try to promote there 4C's message which is Colleagues, Customers, Company, Community. a great message which starts with colleagues meaning it will benefit the next part and so on, its a shame they done actually do this, if you're feeling down, get back on the phone, late for work due to a car crash, get back on the phone, if your whole family is in a life threatening situation, please please just get back on the phone. if you're feeling down, depressed, suicidal and would love to go home due to you not being able to reach your maximum potential...then please go you need it ( but just expect your disciplinary on your desk tomorrow) but please go if that's what you wanna do. 

i was often asked to stay past contracted hours in order to get through the call ques, despite this not being in my contract it was expected otherwise you should say goodbye to your job. You're also bombarded with awful stat expectations, and when you've had a good day? could do better, when you've had a perfect 100% day there is very little recognition or acknowledgment for this, I'm sure a lot of people who are under this pressure want a 100% day just so they don't have to hear the same broken record about how this is all because of you, you're not doing enough you're not saying what we told you, you didn't do this you didn't do that, be prepared to speak like a robot, but please add some character and personality in there (whilst you repeat exactly what we've said and follow a script) 

There is so many things wrong here, at first i felt i could've been harsh but no this is exactly how its run, it's a schoolground mentality with the managers thinking they're the teachers and own you but life changing consequences, which is loosing your job, I'm sorry to anyone who didn't see this and now works there and to anyone who's reading this and doesn't work here..Don't.

headline: Great flexible working
pros: Flexible hours, child friendly, great office conditions and equipment, good health benefits and share option schemes, good 10% pension contribution, annual bonus, free annual shares of £500 per employee, BT and other high street discount schemes.
cons: Regular culling of staff through voluntary and conditional redundancy can leave some departments short of resources. Management top heavy at times and not enough promotion from within the ranks, opting for flashy outsiders from other industries to come in and try their ideas. Share price has reflected huge failures by repeated attempts to bring in new fresh talent, yet shares dropped from highs of almost £5 per share to just under 96 pence. Most grads and apprentices leave or move on to bigger better paid roles within a few years of gaining experience from a Footsie 100 company. Ofcom have fined and ordered the split of BT and Openreach from gaining market dominance, management greed has bled money through scandal headlines in Italy and pensions changes have upset a lot of loyal long service staff who have left in disgust.

headline: Every time you think it can't get any worse, it somehow does
pros: The HR team are so inadequate that I was able to be made redundant by noticing that they had not adhered to employment laws surrounding the redundancy process. Also had not honoured the reasons that they rejected my initial appeal (read: begging to be let go).
cons:
Diligenta acquired my employment by being lucky enough to convince Lloyds to TUPE transfer my department and others over to them, effectively outsourcing their work whilst still reaping the benefits of keeping us to deal with their customers. Well, those benefits I'm sure have not been worth the hassle for the affected products in Halifax Financial Services, Clerical Medical and Scottish Widows. Their "incredible" system BaNCS is dreadful, slow, not user friendly, and the opposite of intuitive. They have strict processes for every requirement which are inflexible and work to the detriment of both customer, and call handler. By having offshore servicing teams the communication within the business to get things done right just falls apart, meaning things are often done wrong several times before it is fixed. 

After moving all the Lloyds Banking Group work from Bristol to Edinburgh (which was managed absolutely atrociously) we faced redundancy or relocation to Aviva who they also work for. The redundancy announcement came roughly a week before March's lockdown at the beginning of a global pandemic, which Diligenta must be very grateful for as it stopped the immediate haemorrhaging of staff who instead reluctantly stayed for the temporary job security - myself included. I was given the old bait-and-switch when I was unluckily moved over to Aviva, as on day 2 of my training, I was then informed the REAL role I would be doing was in an entirely different department to that which I was initially informed I would go into. Working at Aviva was not convenient to me, as it meant my office was now in BS34 instead of BS1 - which as you might gather is a fairly substantial distance which ate into both my wallet (now requiring public transport) and commute time. No financial reimbursement was offered to cover these or adjusted shift times. Diligenta values nothing more than a captive work force, and so I fought my move within Diligenta rather than resigned primarily because they seemed to welcome resignations as the cheapest way of letting the demoralised staff go. 5 months after the move to Aviva I was finally free to leave with redundancy, 13 months after the original announcement and now carrying the scars of deep stress, frustration, anxiety and depression over this time. 

At every point where it felt like normality had resumed after another change for the worse within Diligenta, we were struck with a new change with further ruptured the work environment - whether that was up-skilling without increased salary (ie, more work, same pay), refusal to level out pay discrepancies, increasing staff surveillance by managers, or adding new systems to increase the already burdensome number of different logins and bureaucratic steps needed just to do something like request holiday. They even asked us to download an app which would have a disturbingly wide range of unnecessary accesses to information stored on our personal devices, in order to log our hours despite these already being visible on other systems to the necessary lines of authority.

Internal progression is practically non-existent, they won't inform you if there is a salary increase involved prior to application for some internal moves, and it is a series of tick-box interviews/cover letters which does not actually look at any track record of achievement and so means the empty vessel sounding loudest will often regurgitate enough buzzwords to tick the boxes and get the job ahead of more qualified candidates. 

The above is by no means a complete list of issues within Diligenta, but are as much as I have the energy to outline. If you have other options I would highly recommend you take them before working at Diligenta. They would probably make for an adequate first job, but to echo the words of a manager formerly at Diligenta, don't stay longer than 1-2 years because it will slowly destroy you and will not offer suitable progression or pay rises to sustain any personal growth.

headline: Great for short term
pros: SBS is a great stepping stone for people who wish to further themselves within the financial industry. As my first role within the industry it has taught me a lot in my short time of being here. The atmosphere is professional but not excessive and there are plenty of laughs to be had with your colleagues. During my time here I have unfortunately had a few problems at home and I have to say that Skipton definitely aid you with out-of-office issues that may arise. As a company I feel aided by them and don't feel judged for having a life outside of the workplace.
cons: Unfortunately, the main issue with SBS as a whole is the route for progression. If you are the type of person who is a real go-getter then I would probably advise stearing away from SBS. I was told there was room for progression after reiterating the importance of this to myself many times in my interview process and since being there for a short amount of time I feel like I have already hit a very low ceiling. The problem with this is that it makes colleagues stagnate and become complacent.

headline: A place to grow and show what you can do
pros: The people is Bloomberg's best asset. There are so many talented and nice people to work with and learn from. People are also almost always extremely helpful even though every one has more on their plate than they can realistically handle comfortably. This trains you to become efficient and a multitasker. What I have learned is that even the most impossible things are possible to accomplish by getting the right people to work together.
cons: In certain parts of the organisation, management have a tendency to micro manage and flexibility is almost non-existent. It really depends on who your manager is if you need any type of flexible working - Working from home (ad hoc is easier to get, but as a fixed arrangement you will probably not get more than 1 day a week), flexible working hours, or flexible location of working is not always a possibility - again, it depends on your department and direct manager. Also, in some departments a blaming culture is prevalent, which really affects morale.

headline: If you work hard you will reap the rewards
pros: Lots of friendly and helpful colleagues who are willing to share and collaborate. You get out what you put in, there's a lot to do but you will learn and develop quickly, there are opportunities to learn new and different skills.
cons:
It's extremely fast paced which can be quite intimidating, if you don't keep up you could get lost behind. My advice would be to go at your own pace and complete work to your best ability instead of trying to stretch yourself too thin. 
Lots of opinions and information sharing which can be very noisy and distracting from your day to day tasks. Be strict with yourself about when you catch up on email and Slack otherwise you won't have time to complete your work and could burnout.

headline: In the end, a great place to work
pros:
I previously submitted a terrible review for BPP, after my first six months there. However, having seen the way BPP have reacted to Covid-19, plus changes in attitudes management made before the pandemic, my views have changed.

Managers reacted really well to criticism from the team, changing the way in which they worked with us, and have consulted with us much better than before.

During the pandemic, BPP allowed all staff to work from home without question, except for the tiny minority they had to furlough until September 2020. It also looks like BPP will be offering much more flexibility in terms of working from home, which is excellent for members of staff like I, who have difficulties with mental health, and other health conditions, who have actually had a very positive experience working from home since March.

Although there are obvious, fair criticisms from a minority of students, BPP has dealt with the impact of the pandemic quite well, and has made appropriate changes to working practice. For example, all exams have been moved online until at least August 2021, which has given students some certainty. Additionally, BPP are running Covid-secure face to face exams for those who cannot use our online exam platform, which is excellent.
cons:
Some urgent work can be sprung on staff without any fair warning.

Would like to be given more certainty about working from home - not just a promise of more flexibility.

headline: Amazing place to work
pros:
Some of the core values Unity tries to embrace are "Best Idea Wins", "Go Bold" and "In It Together". I've worked at many companies whose values are allegedly good, but don't actually take action on them. In contrast, Unity seems to really invest in these ideas. They deliver Active Listening training to leaders. They have a whole range of social events. They even have an entire Wellbeing team dedicated to running clubs and socials, sending gifts, and so on (so these responsibilities don't fall on the shoulders of people who are juggling this with other work)! They also have several Employee Resource Groups for people in marginalised groups (like a BIPOC one, an LGBTQ+ one, a women's ERG, and so on). Sustainability is also a core concern, with much discussion and events happening around that.

Every team is managed differently, so your experience may vary, but I am given lots of freedom to shape my job to fit myself, rather than change myself to fit the role. I can explore different technologies, collaborate across the organisation, and get involved in a wide variety of work.

The work is interesting and generously compensated (both in terms of salary and holiday allowance); the people are brilliantly smart, talented, and excellent listeners; and the technology is cutting-edge and exciting to work with. It's the most positive and inspirational workplace I've ever had the pleasure of working at.
cons:
Sometimes too many meetings, especially during the pandemic (as it's a big organisation).

If you're not from a corporate background, the jargon can be off-putting. There is a jargon glossary though!

Many different systems for different tasks. Not a huge problem, just a lot to learn when you first arrive.

Sometimes things are moving so fast, it feels as if we haven't finished one product/solution before we're working on or shipping the next one, which can damage credibility with users (e.g. if something ships with bugs)

headline: No progression in this diversity-obsessed company
pros: Easy role, good work banter and a good social circle of colleagues. Lots of young, energetic employees, central location in the Arndale Tower.
cons: The progression is largely determined by where you sit on the L B G T diversity template that has permeated this company's HR department above every other facet of common sense and consideration on how to run a HR function. If you arent flying that particular flag, you will be ignored and passed over with predictable & sickening regularity. Pay is ok for the basic work you do but it's not a career - if you want to earn less than £24k for the rest of your life this is a good place to stay. Perhaps the worse part of this job is management. They are mainly comprised of failed HR managers who werent industrious enough to get through their CIPD exams so they compensate by dragging junior members of staff into attendance & performance review meetings at every single opportunity. The phrase "managed out" springs to mind - any infraction for lateness (even if evidenced with events beyond your control) is punished with meeting after meeting, followed by gleeful team leaders savouring any opportunity to punish team members for such diverse reasons as childcare, bereavement, illness, etc, followed by further back to back meetings designed to undermine, torment & eventually bin employees off rather than solve problems and look at reasonable adjustments. For a HR department, they sure do make it up as they go along. The only real consistency I saw in this role is that backbiting, underhanded informing on your colleagues was encouraged and rewarded by manager's favouritism. All in this makes for a very negative, toxic and distasteful workplace.

headline: Not a great or enjoyable experience
pros: Few of the people were nice nothing else really
cons: I felt I didn't get any (or much) support here during my time here and the Listings Team Leader did not interact with me at all or knew I was starting on my first day nor did she trained me just left it to another team member to and she didn't know what I was suppose to be doing either ! And on top of it the Team Leader always laughed at people's cases and some her colleagues just gather around her desk and doing the same which I thought was very disrespectful, also what baffles me is that I supposedly done something wrong so I was told not to return and not one word was said to me at the time so of course I didn't have the opportunity to give explanation or defend myself, ok I weren't a permanent staff member- however yet if I wanted time off I had to give a weeks notice - how does that work out exactly ? Story is, aside from that mysterious mistake I supposedly made I was not familiar or too much understanding with the work - all I did was what I was trained to do and I did ask what else or if anything else I be trained on and did ask if there is anything someone can teach me, answer was either 'No' or 'I don't know' - lack of communication and not being straight with people.

headline: Overall positive experience during induction.
pros: The processes and steps are clear and communicated clearly which helps to manage expectations. Queries are responded to which is very important. Lots of time is factored in for proper induction and good focus on the workload given to Lecturers. Professional and friendly staff. Everybody is help to help and support and mean it.
cons: The induction steps and the process could have been managed in a more organised way. i.e. Having all the IT equipment organised and connected in one go - or more could have been arranged in advance to avoid many calls with IT. The onboarding trainings could be managed through a system - for ex. an employee profile rather than excel sheet and etc. It would be good to remove everything that looks and feels old school to lead by example in such a fast paced and progressive business world.

headline: Not as good as people believe
pros: Move dept every 2 to 3 years which keeps the job fresh.  In turn this means a frequent turnover of managers.  You're lucky if you manage to get a decent manager but expect them to move on and fast!  Middle managers are pretty useless many of which have no management experience and no training so you find yourself managed by people who don't have a clue.  On the plus you do get a pension, sick pay and decent maternity package.
cons: Not interested in support grades. Unfair treatment.  Expectation to work much longer hours for zero compensation either money or time off in lieu. Bad performance often not tackled which leaves the hard workers often carrying  a heavier workload.  Training inadequate.  Systems of working often change and employees not consulted.  Staff welfare generally not a concern the organisation says all the right things to tick the right boxes but in practice their staff welfare is pretty non existent.

headline: So glad to have left
pros: Accumulated stock awards are attractive if you are at the Principal Engineer/Director level
cons:
Two years on from my departure and I still struggle to identify anything remotely positive about Cisco beyond staying for share options. Continual, stealth headcount reductions after each quarter's results have gradually removed those with the energy and creativity that Cisco desperately needs to reinvent itself. For those early-in-career, I'm not convinced that having Cisco on the resume/CV helps. My experience is it can hinder you when applying to new roles as you are tarred with having worked in a slow-moving, behemoth company rather than a fast-moving agile start-up.

Let's face it - this is a company that should have owned the whole videoconference market in the wake of COVID-19 via WebEx yet it is Zoom that has stolen both the zeitgeist and the market. That should be enough for the Board to call for Chuck to step down and for them to bring in a visionary technology leader rather than yet another senior salesperson with a strategy that only looks 2 quarters out in a vain attempt to keep Wall St happy...

headline: Still Not Getting It...
pros:
Brand name
Project exposure
Security and stability a large firm brings
Starting to clear out the sub par male, pale, stale leadership
cons:
Pay is awful
Bonus is embarrassing 
L&D opportunities aren’t there - unless you want to do CIMA or ACA there’s no chance of anything meaningful, no masters sponsorship etc
This is no exaggeration, five - ten years behind on the digital agenda. Utterly clueless
Fragmented - partners scrapping for revenue and status. 
Partners are generally nothing special, very few intellectual powerhouses in the firm, mostly sales focussed individuals that were fortuitously aligned to a big-revenue client earlier in their career 
Some partners genuinely view the world in terms of ‘winners’ and ‘losers’ - it would be cringe if it wasn’t so toxic 
Politics are unbearable 
If a partner takes a dislike to you, you may as well resign, seen many careers ruined
Promotions are a joke - there are people who are performing for 1 yr + at the grade above and still cannot get promoted. There have been people selling a lot of work that still get turned down
When you do go for promotion you are put through an interview process and have to provide a business case at even Manager level (something you literally cannot control, given it depends on the work you are aligned to)
Systems are so outdated and lead to a ton of admin
Very much a conform or leave agenda in terms of culture
D&I initiatives more oriented towards protecting partners from embarrassing headlines than actually addressing D&I issues - there have been no substantial policy changes in recruitment for example. 
The consulting practice is basically an advisory firm - generalists do not progress. If you want to progress you need to specialise in a certain, very specific area, which kind of defeats the reason why many people go into consulting in the first place. 
Quality of work is painfully variable - I’ve seen some work that can rival MBB and other work that is so poor I’m almost embarrassed for the client receiving it

headline: Avoid like the plague!
pros:
Some nice people to work with
Good pension scheme
cons:
The culture is really not what it used to be.
Since the new management took over, it has all gone downhill.
Extremely long hours, no work life balance, senior managers and directors email and message at all hours (earliest I got was 5am and latest midnight), even though they claim that ‘they are happy to discuss flexible working’. Flexible meaning, you have to be flexible and around.
Career progression is based on favouritism, or knowing that if they don’t promote, people will definitely leave, and people agreeing to get promotions without a raise with a semi-promise that they will get something the next year. Don’t ask for a raise, you won’t get it and you will end up 
 in their bad books.
The pay is low, the benefits are not great, except for the pension which is pretty good.
Don’t expect bonuses to be of much worth, and they stress that they are discretionary.
They don’t actually care about well-being, people being overworked and underpaid. It’s extremely difficult to get in lieu time for the extra time worked even if your manager knows that you have worked 10-12 hour days.
If you do decide to join, treat this as a temporary gig, most people leave after a couple of years, primarily the ones who are good at their jobs. The rest get promoted to fill roles that are incapable of doing.
Also, forget about training, there is literally no budget for that. They have an internal team who (bless them) do the best they can, but clearly are not going to be able to offer specialised training in areas outside the core bank roles.
Don’t make the same mistake I made to buy into the ‘culture’, it’s at best a facade. Who is left is some senior directors who have no clue what they are doing and destroying anything good left from the culture.

headline: Questionable team dynamics
pros: - VERY big firm - can find any specialist
cons:
- Stress vs Benefits is unreasonable. Consulting in stressful. For some reason it can be more stressful in Accenture due to some particular managers / senior managers. I wasn't lucky and all my projects had at least one regularly screaming team member.

- Nearly not enough projects for all hires. I understand the churn rate in consulting, but firing people because they cannot find a project, while being a junior team member is questionable.

- Promotions are not transparent. The loudest screaming drama person would typically get an early promotion. If you are not ready to be loud and drama - maybe boutique firms will be a better option.

headline: Great to build CV and experience
pros:
(Review of Consulting role)
- Lots of opportunities to work in different industries and types of project without having to change employer every time
- Motivated people
- People are driven to get stuff done
- If you want to follow a particular interest e.g set up a community or run a knowledge sharing session, usually fairly straightforward to get funding/support
- Staff are rewarded well e.g socials, bonus, benefits
- There's money for training
cons:
- A lot of projects expect long hours and big commitment - therefore, can be poor work/life balance
- Everything comes down to profit in the end
- Can be forced into roles that might not be the right for you if you end up in the wrong place at the wrong time
- Difficult to progress beyond Manager if you're more client delivery focused than sales/business growth focused

It isn’t worth it for the little pay.

headline: Dreadful Communications and Poor Staff Management
pros:
The work is genuinely rewarding. 

The Service Users were occasionally challenging but usually great fun to be around. 

Most of the staff I worked with are lovely, caring and diligent people, and I hope to stay in contact with several of them. 

The grounds were (once upon a time) beautiful.
cons:
Management - the attitude of some individuals stinks (others were very supportive). 

Communications are abysmal - top-down, one-way and inefficient beyond nightmare status. Newsletters, clearly designed for online distribution, are printed out and circulated behind a signing sheet. None of the houses had computers or printers, so everything was done on paper, and if you ran out of any forms on the weekend you spent more time trying to scrounge forms from other houses than filling the damn things in. When they eventually find their way 'upstairs' they are typed in to a computer and then apparently forgotten about.

Investment is awful. The fabric of the building and grounds were very poorly maintained - there were innumerable safety issues that we had to live with, such as broken lighting, doors hanging off of hinges, damaged door locks and self-closers, and constant issues with laundry and cooking equipment. The grounds have been let go to wrack and ruin.

The food prepared for the service users is sometimes embarrassing. Crappy ingredients coupled with weird menus and bizarre recipes put together by people whose skill level ran from 'chef' standard to worse than '1st-year-at-Uni'. The site deals with eating disorders but I never met anyone with any form of qualification as a nutritionist or dietician.

Career and professional development is treated as a burden. If you find a course to expand upon a special interest don't even waste your time applying for support or funding.

The worst thing is that the site manager at my location couldn't be bothered to talk to staff. When she does she is often rude. When she visits the service users she is often rude to them and nearly always provokes some kind of incident for the Support Workers to manage after she's gone. And she seems totally oblivious to her purpose (to care for her service users) and her biggest business issue (attracting and retaining staff).

Like so many other places in care, Trust, Loyalty and Flexibility are one-way streets.

headline: Depends on location (this review is mainly for the Heathrow branch)
pros: Working for the company in Knightsbridge was an amazing experience. Colleagues and managers were lovely, but that also depends on which department you're in. I was lucky to be in a nice environment with friendly people who were always there to give support as I was new. Unfortunately, I was only at this location for a short period of time.
cons: Working at the Harrods at Heathrow airport was an overall bad experience for me. The managers were the main problem, never there for support, only there to find something to vent their anger at. The biggest problem was the toxic environment. If you weren't a part of their clique then that's it. One of my colleagues, who I had an argument with, was very close to a certain member of management and basically played it their way to make my life hell when I was there. Things at Heathrow get overlooked as the HR is probably already too busy with the main London store, therefore serious issues that need to be addressed at Heathrow get brushed under the rug.

headline: Personal Experience
pros: Good pay. Other than that nothing.
cons: No team leader and for a big store there was only two managers. Team work was a myth, Saturday I would be alone and expected to do a three person job. This most likely could’ve been the store I worked at but it was horrible. I sometimes wouldn’t get to go on my break because the work needed to be finished by the end of my shift. If it wasn’t I wouldn’t get to go home.

headline: Good culture but Poorly paid
pros: There was a good culture and I made lots of friends and felt well managed. There was opportunity for overtime and overal not a bad place to work
cons: The pay is spectacularly uncompetitive. I left in 2017 on approx £22/£23k per year year into the same role at another company on £35k which, by the end of the year I joined, had increased to £40k. I also felt there was a degree of cronyism that you only got ahead of you knew the right people. I always asked for development but was passed up time and again, mainly I believe due to not being great at their interview style. I always felt like my face didn’t fit and since leaving have had 2 promotions. Maybe I wasn’t ready at the time but I felt like I was sisyphus pushing the rock endlessly up a hill with no let up or reward!

location: Luton, East of England, England, England
headline: Good company but suffers from institutionalised bullying
pros: In house services is a good company to work for. there is a lot to learn and you are supported with training. Unlike many companies, they seem to care about their clients
cons: Where they fail is middle management. There is a huge amount of workplace bullying taking place, especially in FMCG but middle level managers. Lower level staff are overworked and given very little support. If a complaint is raised then its brushed under the carpet or the complaintant is exited from the business. I myslef have suffered form this and its had a very serious effect on my mental health. I have tried to raise issues and get support but been reprimanded by my manager for doing this. Its left me with no alternative other than to look for another job

headline: It was okay
pros:
-Worked on the fragrance counter; interesting to learn about
-Decent pay
cons:
-Very stressful during busy christmas periods. Understaffing meant it was difficult to cope with all of the customers
-As a temporary worker i wasnt given that much training and was thrown into the deep end. Wasnt taught how to issue returns/refunds which made me reliant on other staff who were often busy with their own tasks.
-Very cliquey; as a temporary worker was difficult to make friends with colleagues who were unfriendly and had tight knit existing groups
-Poor management; timetabled me too many hours and didnt listen when i told them. Ended up realising by which point i had become really ill from working long and stressful hours
